DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE DEFENSE ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Dinkins Says Census Bureau Missed 1 Million New Yorkers
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins has accused the Census Bureau of skipping one out of every 13 housing units and missing up to 1 million residents in its preliminary 1990 count of the city's population. Dinkins said Wednesday the city is filing a challenge to the government's figures. Federal aid and representation in Congress are determined by the Census count. ``The 1990 undercount could cost us up to $1 billion in lost federal aid, or $150 for each man, woman and child living in our city,'' he said. Dinkins also said the count could cost the city at least one seat in Congress. The mayor said the Census Bureau failed to count 254,534 housing units, undercounting the city's population by 800,000 to 1 million. The Bureau counted 7.033 million people in the city. The Department of City Planning estimates 8 million people live in the city. ``It is statistically stunning and demographically absurd for the Census Bureau to claim that a city whose resident birth rate has risen by at least 23 percent and which has welcomed more than 800,000 legal immigrants to its shores during the past decade has actually lost population,'' the mayor said. The city was given 15 business days to review the Bureau's 1990 preliminary figures. It did so by analyzing data from the city, Con Edison and the New York Telephone Co., as well as consulting surveys, atlases and aerial photographs. In his letter to Sheila Grimm, regional director of the Census Bureau, Dinkins asked that the bureau review some 11,900 city blocks - approximately 43 percent of the city's more than 28,000 residential blocks. The bureau has said it would take 10 days to review the city's challenge. In a three-block area in one section of Queens, the city counted 567 housing units in what it said was a neighborhood of one-and two-family homes; the Census Bureau counted zero units. Neighborhoods with minority populations, in general, tended to be undercounted by the bureau, said Richard Schaffer, director of the Department of City Planning and chairman of the City Planning Commission. Dinkins said the 1980 undercount, put by the Census Bureau at 450,000, cost New York City some $675 million in federal aid during the ensuing 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaitis: Most Iraqi Soldiers Seem Poor, Disoriented
DOC.TEXT: The bulk of Iraqi forces in Kuwait appear to be poor, confused teen-agers, but crack Republican Guards are tightening their control over the city, Kuwaitis fleeing their country say. Refugees interviewed over the past few days at this border crossing said Iraqi troops were becoming increasingly violent in their campaign to force Kuwaitis to accept Iraqi occupation. Checkpoints every 900 feet are now controlled by at least one Republican Guard, who makes sure that searches are thorough. Neighborhood searches have also become more intense, with whole areas completely cut off with six or eight roadblocks as up to 20 soldiers comb each house, said the refugees, who generally spoke on condition of anonymity to protect family members left behind from possible retribution. About 500 refugees arrived Wednesday, a sharp drop from the more than 6,000 who had poured across the border since Saturday, when Iraq opened it for the first time in more than a month. The numbers tumbled Monday when Iraqi troops began grabbing men under 40 at random from cars trying to cross. Those crossing Wednesday were old men, women and children. Reports of rape, even against Kuwait women, had climbed. A flier distributed in Kuwait on Sunday warned that anyone shooting a gun would be executed and any house from which a gun is fired would be torn down, as would neighboring homes. The Iraqis are already carrying out the threat, with former army or police officers and suspected resistance members disappearing and turning up dead, the refugees said. ``They seem to like blood. This is really a bloody regime,'' said Faisal, a 27-year-old computer programmer. But each checkpoint seems to be operating under a different set of rules in terms of the questions Iraqi soldiers ask, said a Kuwaiti defense department official who visited his country last week. ``They seem to lack stable or strict instructions,'' he said. Refugees said the Iraqi troops were constantly conducting maneuvers. Iraq was attempting to engender respect in Kuwait for President Saddam ussein, who has annexed the oil-rich emirate. The seaside corniche was hung every few yards with his portrait and Friday prayer leaders were told to put in a good word about him in their sermons. When they refused and concentrated on prayers for salvation, prayer sermons were canceled, the refugees said. The Iraqi troops are grabbing as many consumer goods as they can, refugees said, either by outright theft or extortion. At a checkpoint, for example, an Iraqi soldier might drop a bullet into a car's trunk and accuse the driver of being a member of the resistance. The driver hands over a watch or some cigarettes and the accusation is dropped. ``If your car breaks down or you run out of gas and you have to leave it, you can forget about the tires and engine,'' said a 22-year-old student. ``You feel everybody (among the Iraqi troops) is poor and badly fed,'' said a prominent economist who fled Monday. ``They beg for food and water.'' Iraqi forces have slaughtered most of the horses in Kuwait and even zoo animals for food, the refugees said. The Iraqi army was also trying to take control of all private-run supermarkets in Kuwait. The student said the combat-readiness of the Iraqis was questionable, with many of the teen-age soldiers appearing fearful of entering neighborhoods where soldiers had been shot at. ``It's obvious they are frightened. The Iraqi soldiers are respected too much in the eyes of the world,'' he said. The bulk of Iraqi troops seem to be about 16 years old, poor and still befuddled about what they are doing in Kuwait, refugees said. The adolescent soldiers repeatedly tell Kuwaits that they had been instructed before the Aug. 2 invasion that they were moving into Kuwait for maneuvers with other Arab armies to prepare for an attack on Israel. Not all Iraqi troops are not hostile, the Kuwaitis said. ``Sometimes if I am nice with them, they are nice with me,'' said the economist. ``They say, `I am Arab, Islamic, like you.''

DOC.HEAD: Computer `Hiccups,' But Magellan Keeps on Mapping Venus
DOC.TEXT: ``Hiccups'' keep plaguing a computer aboard the Magellan spacecraft, which nevertheless has completed more than 30 consecutive orbits making radar pictures of cloud-covered Venus, NASA says. The pesky malfunctions are in the backup computer that helps point the orbiter. The same computer - one of four aboard Magellan - played a major role when engineers lost contact with the spacecraft Aug. 16 and again on Aug. 21, although the precise cause of those incidents remains unknown. Despite the glitches, the spacecraft on Wednesday morning completed its 30th consecutive orbit mapping the cracked, volcanic landscape of Venus. Magellan, which arrived at Venus on Aug. 10, is making almost eight orbits daily. It began its mapping mission on Saturday. ``Since Venus is almost the same size as Earth, the 30-orbit image patch ... would drape an area on Earth extending from Los Angeles to Albuquerque and from the North Pole to nearly the South Pole,'' NASA said in a statement. Pictures released in past weeks have shown long ridges and valleys, networks of faults, large flows of solidified lava and volcanic craters. The most recent glitch happened Monday, when the backup to Magellan's main computer got a set of false alerts from the backup pointing computer. The spacecraft wasn't operating on either backup computer, so mapping continued. Other glitches happened just after Magellan reached Venus, then again on Sept. 4. Engineers nicknamed the malfunctions ``hiccups,'' said Steve Wall, Magellan experiment representative at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Magellan traveled a looping, 948-million-mile path to Venus after being launched from the shuttle Atlantis in May 1989. Magellan and Venus are now almost 156 million miles from Earth.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's `Line in the Sand' Is Drawn In Saudi Desert
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's promised ``line in the sand'' defense of Saudi Arabia is anything but linear. Troops are scattered in clumps near highways, potential desert tank routes and the kingdom's oil fields. From these carefully chosen locations, the U.S. military commander believes he could fight a mobile desert war. But there is also concern about sustaining troops and equipment in such configurations given the region's harsh conditions. The United States has exercised troops in the Middle East but never fought a war in the region. History is its guide. ``Look at Rommel, look at North Africa, the Arab-Israeli wars and all the rest of them,'' Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia, said in an interview last week. ``A war in the desert is a war of mobility and lethality,'' Schwarzkopf said. ``It's not a war of straight lines drawn in the sand, where you dig in and say, `I will defend here or die.' Most people who do that die.'' The Marines and the Army are splitting the burden of forming the defensive clusters. Marines are guarding the north-south coastal highway into Saudi Arabia from Kuwait and also the kingdom's oil fields and support facilities not far from the coast. Those would be the major prize if Iraq were to invade, but the United States has positioned a sizebable ground force and arranged for air-to-ground support. That would make if difficult for Iraq to move down the coastal roads. ``Saddam Hussein's just got to look around and say to himself, `I'm over my head,''' Marine Maj. Gen. Royal N. Moore Jr. said recently when asked about the size of the deployment. Saddam's other option for a ground invasion would be inland over the desert, where Arab forces form the front lines and heavy American ground forces are beginning o fan out behind them in defensive formations. The M-1 tanks and heavy artillery of the 24th and 197th mechanized infantries are the backbone of these forces, and several more heavy units are en route. Smaller, more mobile vehicles carrying Tow anti-tank missiles and other weapons also are becoming a more common sight across certain areas of the desert. These units are drilled in speeding toward oncoming tanks, firing at them and rushing back to base camps to rearm for more combat. Attack helicopters with anti-tank systems would be deployed to do much of the same from the air. There are vast stretches between some of the American camps. But U.S. planners say the more mobile of the ground forces would have time to reach these areas if Saddam chose them for a route of attack. They consider such a decision unlikely because these open areas generally are locations U.S. commanders believe Iraq would have difficulty supplying with fuel and ammunition. Sustainability also is a question high in the minds of the American commanders. Some spare parts, fuel trucks and other supplies are still hard to come by. The M-1s and other equipment are being used as little as possible because of the shortages. ``We're being very careful what we do with the equipment,'' said Gen. Barry McCaffrey, commander ofthe 24th Infantry. ``It will be a tremendous challenge to build the logistics system needed for maintenance, management and parts distribution 7,000 miles from home.'' To help sustain the force, National Guard and Reserve units are being brought in to convert salt water to drinking water and provide transportation and other support services that would be crucial if fighting breaks out.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher's Travel East: A Family Reunion
DOC.TEXT: In many ways British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's first visit this week to two new East European democracies, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, was like a family reunion. She hailed both for their bloodless revolutions, which ended decades of Communist rule and led to elections this year that installed the countries' first democratic governments in more than 40 years. They had, she declared, returned ``once more to their rightful place in Europe.'' But Mrs. Thatcher, who traveling to Switzerland today on the last leg of a six-day trip, singled out for special attention Hungary's Prime Minister Joszef Antall. He is the only true political soulmate the upheaval in Eastern Europe has produced for the British Conservative Party leader. ``We believe in the same things and act on our beliefs,'' she told Antall, who has seen inflation hit 25 percent to 30 percent and unemployment rise under his center-right government, headed by his Democratic Forum party. ``The fact that you are the only conservative government in Eastern Europe merits topmost consideration,'' she said. Mrs. Thatcher seemed less at ease perched on a stool in a Prague coffee bar at 10 o'clock in the morning with Czechoslovakia's Vaclav Havel. The playwright turned president joked and laughed, and had a beer. Mrs. Thatcher smiled politely and had a coffee. In Hungary, during a 1984 trip under communist rule, she'd been through the usual stuff of official visits - rounds of wreath-laying, handshaking, banquets, walkabouts, political talks and news conferences. This time everything was different. If the Hungarian guards of honor looked a shade drab in green fatigues it was because they have abandoned their Soviet-style uniforms and red stars, and the new uniforms are still being designed. In Prague, a square she named after Winston Churchill at a small ceremony formerly bore the name of a Communist Party general secretary, Antonin Zapotocky. In 1984, the nearest she got to a whiff of private enterprise was a Budapest street market. This time she toured Budapest's fledgling stock exchange. The first in the East bloc in more than four decades, it trades just one hour a day, has fewer than 50 members and is having a tough time getting Hungarians to buy shares. ``Small is beautiful,'' commented a Hungarian official showing her around. ``Well, it's start,'' replied Mrs. Thatcher. ``It's really wonderful to see it done this way. ... You are ahead of Moscow.'' In a similar vein, she interrupted her husband, Denis, when he sought production figures from one of Hungary's new entrepreneurs, a former Olympic gold javelin gold medallist, Miklos Nemeth. Nemeth has set up a javelin-manufacturing company. ``You musn't ask question like that, he's only just started,'' she interjected. ``Come back in three or four years' time and he'll tell you.''

DOC.HEAD: Boy in Critical Condition After Dog Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Butler Township ...' and 7th `The aunt ...' to CORRECT that 11-year-old was cousin sted aunt.
DOC.TEXT: A 2-year-old boy mauled by six Rottweiler dogs at his grandmother's house was in critical condition Wednesday, authorities said. The Tuesday night attack left Steven Selfridge of Saxonburg with puncture wounds and damage to his windpipe and one lung, according to Dr. Max Ramenofsky of Allegheny General Hospital. The child also lost a lot of blood, Ramenofsky said. Butler Township police said Steven and his 11-year-old cousin were playing at the home when one of the Rottweilers, a breed known for strong neck and jaw muscles, came onto the porch and dragged him into a fenced-in yard. A half-dozen dogs then mauled the boy until he was unconscious, police said. The boy's grandmother, Alma Evanick, had been in the coronary care unit of Butler Memorial Hospial, said Butler Township Police Chief Gary Garman. One dog lived at the house and the five others were brought by the visiting 11-year-old, authorities said. The cousin, Jamie Ross, tried to stop the attack by shielding him with her body, rescuers said. ``She's the real hero here,'' said Chris Jones, a paramedic with Butler Ambulance Service who was the first to arrive at the scene. ``At one point she tried to cover the little boy with her body. ``When she saw it wasn't going go work, she ran into the house and called 911.'' Jamie, who was bitten, was treated at Butler County Memorial Hospital and released. Jones rescued the boy by putting on protective firefighter's gear and chasing away the dogs with blasts from a fire extinguisher. The dogs were being held in quarantine at the home, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Journalist, Ambassador's Daughter, Kidnapped in Bogota
DOC.TEXT: Shortly after the daughter of Colombia's ambassador to Canada was abducted, armed men kidnapped a journalist whose family owns the country's leading newspaper and shot his chauffeur to death, police said. It was not immediately known if drug traffickers, who are at war with the government, were responsible for Wednesday's abductions. The newspaper La Prensa reported Wednesday that the Medellin cocaine cartel had abducted the six journalists missing since Aug. 30. It said the six were taken in a bid to pressure the government into negotiating the terms under which drug traffickers could be tried in Colombia. La Prensa said it received the information from a cartel spokesman. The journalists, including Diana Turbay, daughter of former President Julio Cesar Turbay, disappeared on their way to interview a guerrilla leader in the countryside. The ambassador's daughter, Marina Montoya de Perez, was abducted in Bogota several hours before the nighttime kidnapping in the capital of Francisco Santos. His family owns El Tiempo, Colombia's largest newspaper. Santos was taken by a group of heavily armed men traveling in two jeeps who shot his driver to death before forcing him into one of the jeeps, the police said in a report. Also Wednesday, the newspaper El Espectador, citing official sources, reported that drug traffickers had offered $280,000 to those who helped a man accused of killing a presidential candidate escape from prison. Jaime Rueda Rocha fled Bogota's La Picota penitentiary wearing a disguise and apparantly aided by a man posingas his lawyer, a police report said. Rueda was one of three suspects being held for the murder of Sen. Luis Carlos Galan, the popular presidential candidate shot ato death on Aug. 18, 1989. His death set off the government's war with Medellin cartel leaders, who authorities say masterminded Galan's killing. Officials say Rueda helped coordinate the cartel's bombing campaigns during the past year and is one of the country's most dangerous terrorists. Earlier this month, President Cesar Gaviria decreed that drug traffickers who turn themselves in and confess their crimes can be tried in Colombia, and not be extradited to the United States - the fate they fear most. There has been no official response from the cartel to Gaviria's offer, which provides reduced sentences of up to 50 percent to surrendering drug traffickers. Drug traffickers issued a communique on Tuesday saying they will maintain the cease-fire in their attacks against the goverment, which have claimed the lives of about 550 people this year. They declared the unilateral cease-fire on July 27. ``For the moment, it is not in our interest to reactivate the bomb attacks in any area of the country,'' said a statement bearing the letterhead ``The Extraditables,'' as the Medellin cartel calls itself.

DOC.HEAD: Buchanan, Rosenthal & Buckley: Strife on the Op-Ed Page
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The liveliest Middle East battlefield is the op-ed page, where Abe accuses Pat of anti-Semitism, Pat says Abe executed ``a contract hit'' on him for the Israel lobby, and the normally combative Bill tries to mediate. The stateside war of the columnists involves A.M. Rosenthal, Patrick Buchanan and William F. Buckley Jr. in a debate over U.S. Middle East policy that seems to have almost forgotten about Iraq. Fighting began in the last week of August on ``The McLaughlin Group,'' the television talk show on which Buchanan is a regular. Asked if he thought war with Iraq was inevitable, Buchanan said no, and added: ``There are only two groups that are beating the drums right now for war in the Middle East, and that is the Israeli Defense Ministry and its amen corner in the United States.'' ``Those are fighting words,'' host John McLaughlin noted. Rosenthal, former executive editor and now columnist for The New York Times, thought so, too. He wrote in Friday's column: ``We are not dealing here with country-club anti-Semitism but with the blood libel that often grows out of it: Jews are not like us but are others, with alien loyalties for which they will sacrifice the lives of Americans.'' Rosenthal denounced Buchanan's ``venom about Jews. In one column, he denounced five people for supporting military action against Iraq - all Jews, including me.'' The Buchanan-Rosenthal feud is part of a broader rift among conservative columnists over whether the U.S. is overextending itself militarily in the post-Cold War world, particularly in the Persian Gulf. ``It's been a long time since columnists have mattered so much,'' Peggy Noonan, a former speech writer for Ronald Reagan and George Bush, said last week. ``It's exciting.'' In a column published Wednesday in the New York Post and elsewhere, Buchanan denied Rosenthal's charge. ``What we have here, friends, is a contract hit, done, my guess, in collusion with the same folks who used to feed me all that good stuff on Jesse Jackson when I was considered more reliable. For the one character who has been howling about the `amen corner' (remark) is Abe Foxman of the Anti-Defamation League.'' Why else, argued the former aide to presidents Nixon and Reagan, would Rosenthal have waited three weeks to write about a remark he found so upsetting? Once, Buchanan wrote, ``I was an uncritical apologist for Israel,'' but became disillusioned for a variety of reasons, including Israel's treatment of Palestinians, its attempts to spy on the United States and ``the caustic, cutting cracks about my (Roman Catholic) church and popes from both Israel and its amen corner in the United States.'' On Wednesday's editorial page, the Post sided with Rosenthal. Besides the column in which Buchanan listed Americans with Jewish names who favored an attack on Iraq, there was one in which he wrote that in case of war Americans would march ``up that bloody road to Baghdad ... kids with names like McAllister, Murphy, Gonzales, and Leroy Brown.'' ``The names in this list are chosen just as carefully, we believe, as the names on his list of alleged warmongers: the Rosenthals and the Krauthammers and so forth,'' the Post editorialized. Meanwhile, in Wednesday's Daily News, Buckley tried to bring some perspective to the fight, which he called ``the hot talk among journalists and politics-minded intellectuals.'' Peacemaker was an unlikely role for a man who has long baited guests on his aptly-named television program, ``Firing Line,'' and who once came close to slugging Gore Vidal on live national television after Vidal called him a ``crypto Nazi.'' Buckley described both columnists as his friends. The occasionally volatile Rosenthal had ``gone ballistic,'' he said, and Buchanan had been ``insensitive to those fine lines that tend publicly to define racially or ethnically offensive analysis or rhetoric.'' ``The Buchanans need to understand the nature of sensibilities in an age that coexisted with Auschwitz,'' he wrote. ``And the Rosenthals need to understand that clumsy forensic manners are less than a genocidal offense...'' Rosenthal returned a telephone call Wednesday, thus getting the last word - or at least the latest one. Buchanan did not call after a message was left for him. Rosenthal said he had not written earlier about the ``amen corner'' remark because he had been away at a conference in Norway - ``on hatred, appropriately enough'' - and on vacation. ``Pat Buchanan is no longer my problem,'' he said. ``He is now the problem of people who print him and put him on the air. Most of all, he's Pat Buchanan's problem.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Ready To Talk On Ending Worsening War, Says Top U.S. Official
DOC.TEXT: Sickness, starvation and the possibility of further fighting are on the rise in Liberia, but rival guerrilla chiefs are willing to talk peace, a senior U.S. diplomat said after meeting the leaders. Herman Cohen, U.S. assistant secretary of state for African affairs, had put himself at considerable personal risk in traveling to the civil war-ravaged land, where sporadic fighting continues. ``The prospects for increased warfare are growing,'' Cohen told a news conference Wednesday in Abidjan after returning from the visit. ``I feel the situation in Liberia is deteriorating. More and more people are in danger of starvation and death from diseases, especially a growing cholera threat,'' Cohen said. He said conditions worsened after President Samuel Doe, accused by the rebels of corruption and human rights abuses, was captured and killed last week by the rebel forces of Prince Johnson. Reprisals against Doe supporters have been reported and many Doe loyalists are still refusing to surrender to rebels for fear of being killed. Rival rebel forces have also clashed. Cohen spoke hours after the commander of a West African multinational army sent to end the fighting in Liberia announced his 3,000 troops have a new mandate to launch ``a total offensive'' to end the 9-month-old war. Nigeria and Ghana on Wednesday were preparing to send another 1,000 soldiers to Monrovia. They were waiting in Freetown to board ships for the besieged capital. More than 5,000 people, mostly civilians, have died in the conflict. They were killed mainly because of their tribal affiliation. Earlier Wednesday, Cohen crossed the border from Ivory Coast to go behind the lines of rebel leader Charles Taylor, who controls most of Liberia. The U.S. envoy said he found the man many accuse of prolonging the war ``in a negotiating mood.'' On Tuesday, he flew to Monrovia aboard a U.S. Marine helicopter and met with rival rebel chief Johnson, whose forces control Liberia's capital. ``He was helpful and pro-democratic,'' Cohen said. Johnson, a former Taylor lieutenant, has embraced West African Economic Community plans to use their task force to force a cease-fire and install an interim government to organize fair elections. He has said he wants to return to the barracks where he started off as an officer of Doe. Taylor says his men will fight until the West Africans withdraw. He has said he wants democracy but that he also would be unhappy to see anyone but himself lead Liberia for up to five years after the conflict ends. Cohen said both rebel leaders ``said they would like to see Liberia with a truly democratic system and would cooperate in organizing that. ``I have the feeling that Charles Taylor is prepared to negotiate everything. I think he feels that peace is more important than war,'' Cohen said. In response to questions, he did not rule out aid for the West African army from Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia. ``Everything is going to be reviewed,'' he said, having reported back to President Bush. The United States has been under considerable pressure to send troops to stop the bloodshed, which began when Taylor's fighters invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24 to topple Doe. Before cutting aid in 1985, the United States gave Doe's administration half a billion dollar in aid despite repeated charges of human rights violations. Doe took power in a bloody 1980 coup.

DOC.HEAD: Dark-Horse GOP Candidate Out of Money, Patience
DOC.TEXT: Pierre Rinfret, the Republicans' last-minute, bottom-of-the-barrel choice to run against Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo, is out of money, out a campaign manager and practically out of the race. John Denny, Rinfret's deputy campaign manager, said Wednesday there was ``a strong possibility'' Rinfret will stop actively campaigning because of money woes. The millionaire economist, who in recent months had been derided by prominent members of his own party as a ``buffoon'' and ``brainless wonder,'' accused state GOP leaders of failing to back him financially. ``Our financial situation is so desperate that I'm probably going to have to shut down our entire operation this Friday,'' Rinfret wrote to GOP leaders Tuesday. ``I thought you should know that all of our money is gone.'' The 66-year-old candidate would not elaborate on the statement. Also on Wednesday, State Assemblyman John Faso, Rinfret's campaign manager, said in a statement he was ``no longer part of the campaign.''``It has been mutually decided that the campaign would take a different direction,'' he said. William Simon, Rinfret's campaign finance chairman, also defected. ``I told him I'm not a fund-raiser, that's it,'' Simon said. ``I wish him well.'' Rinfret's dark-horse challenge to Cuomo's bid for a third, four-year term marks the first run for public office for the former unpaid adviser to President Nixon. Desperate GOP officials recruited Rinfret in May after a host of prominent Republicans refused to take on Cuomo, including Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp and Sen. Alfonse D'Amato. D'Amato at one point called a race against Cuomo a ``kamikaze mission.'' A statewide poll released this week had Cuomo as the choice of 60 percent of 821 voters surveyed. Rinfret had less than 15 percent. The survey by the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion has a margin of error of four points. During the campaign, Rinfret has called for the possible sale of the New York City subway system and invited a TV reporter to his inauguration - with the suggestion she leave her husband at home. His academic credentials were questioned after he distributed a biography that gave him the title ``Dr.,'' which he claimed to be entitled to because of a diploma from a French university. Cuomo has reported having about $8 million in his campaign fund. Rinfret has reported raising about $900,000, including a $500,000 loan from himself. Denny refused to say how much was left in the Rinfret campaign kitty except that it was ``not much.'' John McArdle, a spokesman for state Senate Majority Leader Ralph Marino, would not say how much, if any, money Rinfret would be given by Republican leaders, but he added: ``We can't let him fold up shop.'' ``It's in all of our interests ... to help our gubernatorial candidate and we intend to help him to the extent we can,'' McArdle said. This close to the Nov. 6 election, Rinfret's name can be removed from the ballot only if he dies or moves out of state. Some GOP leaders said Rinfret should have kept quiet for the sake of the party. ``It certainly puts his campaign in reverse gear,'' said John Cochrane, a state assemblyman and Suffolk County GOP chairman. ``It makes all our campaigns more difficult when the standardbearer is obviously going through a difficult time and goes public with it.''

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Judge in North Case Assigned to Poindexter Panel
DOC.TEXT: One of two judges who voted to set aside the Iran-Contra convictions of Oliver L. North has been assigned to the panel that will hear John M. Poindexter's appeal. Circuit Judge David Sentelle will sit on the panel reviewing Poindexter's convictions along with judges Abner Mikva and Douglas H. Ginsburg, the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here said in an order made public Wednesday. In July, Sentelle joined Judge Laurence Silberman in setting aside North's three Iran-Contra convictions. The judges ordered a hearing to determine if references to the testimony that North gave Congress under a grant of limited immunity from prosecution had unfairly seeped into the former White House aide's trial. Poindexter, national security adviser in the Reagan administration, was convicted of five counts of lying and obstructing congressional investigations of the Iran-Contra affair. He was given a six-month sentence but is free pending appeal. Both Poindexter and North testified before congressional committees about the Iran-Contra affair under immunity grants that bar prosecutors from using what they said as evidence against them. The appeals court set arguments on the case for Feb. 28.
DOC.HEAD: FCC Gives Chicago License to `More Qualified' Applicant
DOC.TEXT: The owners of WSNS-TV in Chicago lost a lengthy license renewal battle when the Federal Communications Commission said a competing applicant was more deserving to run the station. The commission granted Monroe Communications Corp. a license to build a new TV station using channel 44. It said Monroe was more qualified than the current licensee, Video 44, which had switched the station's format to a subscription movie service. The FCC rarely denies license renewals and had given Video 44 a renewal in 1989. But the commission reconsidered the case under orders from a federal appeals court in Washington. Video 44 may appeal the decision to the appeals court. Station officials did not return a call Wednesday seeking comment. ---
DOC.HEAD: Panel Calls for Large Increase in Drug Treatment Aid
DOC.TEXT: Public spending on drug abuse treatment should be increased by more than $2 billion to help more users quit their drug habits, a panel of experts recommends. ``Treatment needs to be recognized as a more important component of drug policy than it has been in recent years,'' Lawrence S. Lewin, chairman of the Institute of Medicine committee that studied the problem, said Wednesday. ``It is time we allocated sufficient resources so that everyone who needs drug treatment will be able to get it,'' he said. An estimated 5.5 million people in the United States need treatment for drug abuse or dependence, according to the panel's report, which was requested by Congress. But in 1987, the latest year for which figures were available, only about 650,000 received treatment in public programs and 200,000 were treated in private programs, the report said. ---
DOC.HEAD: Report: Birth Spacing Could Save Millions of Lives
DOC.TEXT: Millions of infant deaths could be prevented if women in developing nations increased the length of time between births, an independent agency has reported. ``Birth intervals of less than two years are strongly and consistently associated with higher mortality,'' the Population Crisis Committee said in a report Wednesday. When there is less than two years between births, the risk of the second child dying in infancy is increased by between 60 percent and 70 percent, the study said. And it doubles the chance of the earlier child dying by age 5. ``Family planning should be the first step toward improving child survival,'' said Sharon L. Camp, vice president of the committee, which advocates provision of contraceptives and family planning programs. ``Through family planning the cycle of weak mothers giving birth to weak children can be broken,'' Camp said. While admitting that accurate statistics are difficult to collect in many developing nations, the report estimates that 10 million infants and 4 million children age 1 to 5 die each year. About 1.8 million of these deaths could be prevented by extending the interval between births to two years, the study estimates. The study also said infant and child deaths could be reduced by as many as 3 million annually through the use of family planning services to delay first births for young women and to space them out later.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Warns of Bombing Threat in Manila
DOC.TEXT: Americans are being warned about ``a possible imminent terrorist bombing'' in Manila, where talks on the future of U.S. military bases in the Philippines are underway. ``The U.S. government believes this threat to be both specific and credible,'' the State Department said in a statement late Wednesday, linking the possible bombing to the communist New People's Army. The department said the danger was ``in the vicinity of Roxas Boulevard in Manila.'' Several hotels, the U.S. Embassy and the central bank building where the base talks are being held lie along the boulevard, which runs from near the Manila airport to the heart of the city. Also on the street is a U.S. government residential and recreational compound, Seafront, that was the site of a bombing last year that was blamed on communist rebels. No one was injured. The New People's Army has been trying to overthrow the Philippine government for more than two decades. There have been several bombings within the last few weeks, but the government of President Corazon Aquino has blamed most of them on right-wing rebel soldiers. The base talks, which opened Tuesday, aim to produce a new agreement for the future of the U.S. military in the Philippines. The presence of 40,000 U.S. armed forces personnel and dependents, most at Clark Air Base and Subic Naval Base, has been the target of large-scale protests. Richard Armitage, the chief U.S. negotiator at the talks, said the American presence will be reduced. The State Department has issued several warnings to U.S. citizens in the past about general threats against Americans in the Philippines, but the one issued Wednesday night was unusually specific.

DOC.HEAD: Former GOP Governor Launches Comeback Bid in Alaska
DOC.TEXT: Former Republican Gov. Walter J. Hickel has jumped into Alaska's gubernatorial race at the last minute as a third-party candidate. The 71-year-old developer launched his surprise comeback bid Wednesday under the banner of the Alaskan Independence Party, whose ticket, led by John Lindauer, withdrew to let Hickel in. Sen. Jack Coghill, who was the lieutenant governor candidate on the Republican ticket with nominee Arliss Sturgulewski, switched to the third-party ticket with Hickel. Some politicians said Hickel's entry into the race would work to the benefit of the Democratic candidate, former Anchorage Mayor Tony Knowles, by splitting the GOP vote and throwing Sturgulewski's campaign into disarray. Hickel was known as a champion of development while governor from 1966 to 1969, when he was appointed Interior Secretary by President Nixon. He was dismissed in 1970 for his inability to get along with the White House. ``The spirit of Alaska has been lost in recent years,'' Hickel said in announcing his comeback bid. Hickel, who wants to build a natural gas pipeline, liquefaction plant and port to export gas to Asia, said he offers a can-do attitude many Alaskans had found lacking in the election campaign. ``I'm not one to study things to death,'' he said. ``I get things done.'' Papers nominating Hickel and Coghill were filed with the state a half-hour before the 5 p.m. deadline. Hickel enters the race six weeks before Election Day without a campaign headquarters and without having raised any money. But he said, ``The best campaign office I know is right out there on the streets and in the villages.'' Hickel is owner of a company that builds and operates hotels and shopping centers in Alaska. Sturgulewski, forced to scramble to find a new running mate, chose Anchorage businessman Jim Campbell, who came in a strong second to her in the Aug. 28 GOP primary. ``It's an unfortunate thing for Alaska politics,'' she said of Coghill's defection. ``I'm fortunate to be a running mate with someone who doesn't play those kinds of games.'' Coghill said he made the switch because conservatives were not being won over by the Sturgulewski campaign. Democratic Gov. Steve Cowper, who is not seeking a second term, said he believes the development will help Knowles. ``Alaska politics has always been a Wild West show, and it looks like this is the shootout at the GOP corral,'' he said. The Alaskan Independence Party was the vehicle used in previous gubernatorial campaigns by fringe candidate Joe Vogler, a miner who argued that Alaska is unfairly and illegally treated as a colony by the federal government.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down In Tokyo, Stocks Dip
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined against the Japanese yen on Thursday, while share prices edged down. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average fell 123.19 points, or 0.52 percent, ending the day at a year low of 23,602.98. The index lost 158.65 points on Wednesday. The dollar closed at 137.05 yen, down exactly one yen from Wednesday's 138.05-yen finish. It opened at 137.20 yen and ranged between 136.45 yen and 137.40 yen. ``The dollar fell as investors bought back the yen against European currencies as part of their position adjustments,'' said Naohiko Yasuda, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. After decreasing their yen holding positions since Monday, investors were once again buying the Japanese currency on Thursday, he said. The dollar strengthened earlier this week when investors began selling the yen they had overbought in the past weeks, he said. On the stock exchange, the index rose early in the morning, helped by bargain hunting following its decline Wednesday. But its strength did not last because of widespread pessimism and uncertainties in the market due to recent declines, traders said. Masashi Wakabayashi, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co., said a newspaper report about expected losses among medium-sized securities houses during the first half of fiscal 1990, which ends Sept. 30, also discouraged investors. ``Although many people basically had expected poor business performance by the securities houses, when they actually saw it reported, investors, especially individuals, got discouraged,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: The National Enquirer may let Lisa Bonet's lawyers look over a photographic negative of her baby daughter to prove her claim against a drugstore chain. Bonet contends the negative was sold to the tabloid by a Reseda, Calif., drugstore clerk from a roll of the actress' film brought in for developing. The Enquirer initially refused to let lawyers see the negative, but they may now allow a peek, said William Weston, a lawyer for the American Drug Stores Inc. chain. Bonet's attorneys said the negative will prove the clerk stole it to sell to the newspaper. ``We're trying to work things out of court,'' said Ralph Loeb, one of Bonet's lawyers. The Enquirer was not named in the lawsuit over the photo it published in 1989 of Bonet's then month-old baby, Zoe Kravitz. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Ricky Skaggs' children get around. The country singer said Tuesday he picked up the nickname ``Mr. Mom'' by taking his brood of four with him on the road over the summer. ``They rode one of the top 10 roller coasters in the country at Worlds of Fun in Kansas City, saw the rodeo in Cheyenne (Wyoming) and have hit the midways at the Montana and South Dakota state fairs,'' Skaggs said. The children range in age from 6 months to 12 years. Skaggs is known for such hits as ``Country Boy'' and ``Lovin' Only Me.'' --- KNOXVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - A Hollywood producer wants to base a TV drama on the life and times of Lamar Alexander, ex-governor turned university president. ``It would be a one-hour (weekly) story with multiple characters,'' producer Bernard Schwartz said Tuesday. ``The center would be president of the university.'' Schwartz, producer of such films as ``Coal Miner's Daughter'' and ``Sweet Dreams,'' said he is trying to sell the networks on the series. Alexander, a Republican, was governor of Tennessee for eight years. He left office in 1986 and became president of the University of Tennessee. Alexander said Wednesday he likes the idea for the show. --- MIAMI BEACH, Fla. (AP) - Industrialist Victor Posner, sentenced to community service for the homeless in a tax evasion case, has given $607,000 to the cause. Posner, chairman of Royal Crown Cola Co., handed over a check Wednesday to be split by the National Coalition for the Homeless and a Los Angeles-based homeless group. Posner pleaded no contest in 1988 to evading $1.2 million in federal taxes by fraudulently inflating the value of land he donated to a college in the 1970s. He was fined $4 million and ordered to give $3 million to the homeless. He was also ordered to perform 5,000 hours of community service related to the homeless. Court records show he has not completed the work. Royal Crown spokesman Phil Dudek said the contribution was unrelated to Posner's tax case. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moving on some sports circuits.
DOC.TEXT: George Steinbrenner says he misses the Yankees, and he still resents Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent for his lifetime ban. ``I'd love to be back up at the stadium,'' the former boss of the Yankees said in a recent interview. ``I miss my players and the player talk.'' Steinbrenner said he did nothing to justify even a suspension and that he volunteered to step aside from day-to-day management of the team only because Vincent was going to suspend him for two years anyway. ``It was not a punishment; it was an agreement, pure and simple,'' Steinbrenner said. While he accepts the consequences, he adds, ``I'm not happy with the way the agreement is turning out.'' Vincent ruled July 30 that Steinbrenner violated the rules of baseball in paying $40,000 to a gambler, allegedly to dig up dirt on a ballplayer.

DOC.HEAD: Shrimping Limits Debated Along the Gulf Coast
DOC.TEXT: A proposal to curtail the Gulf Coast shrimping season to protect red snapper that get caught up and die in shrimp nets would imperil a $1.2 billion industry, shrimpers say. ``I'd like to see you close your business down for three months and make a living,'' Texas Shrimp Association president Harry Lassaigne argued Wednesday at a hearing of the Gulf of Mexico Fishery Management Council. The council, made up of federal and state fishery officials from five Gulf Coast states, was expected to vote today on a proposal to ban trawling in May, June and July, beginning next year. On Tuesday, a sub-panel of the council voted down the proposal. But the vote was non-binding. Government marine researchers say red snapper stocks are dwindling rapidly, with 10 million to 12 million of the fish dying in shrimp nets each year. The shrimp association disputes those figures because sampling of bycatch - unwanted species caught in shrimp nets - stopped in 1982, and argues that curtailing trawling would endanger an industry that employs 137,000 people along the Gulf Coast. Fishermen argued, however, that the gulf's snapper industry is in greater need of protecting. ``The Gulf of Mexico isn't a limitless source of fish,'' Florida fisherman Bob Zales said. ``The bycatch is a definite problem. If you're not going to do anything about the bycatch of shrimpers, it's not fair to impose quotas on others.'' Zales and other charter boat operators said they already face limits on the number of red snapper they can catch in Florida waters and elsewhere. ``You can't expect me to suffer more economic difficulty while someone's nets drag the bottom and kill baby fish,'' Zales said. About 500 people attended Wednesday's hearing, including 75 shrimpers of Valley Interfaith, a political action group from Port Isabel, Texas. At least 90 percent of that town's 8,000 residents are employed in the shrimping industry.

DOC.HEAD: New Job? Great, But What's That Smell?
DOC.TEXT: The sweet smell of success is wafting from the city's trash, with more than 100,000 New Yorkers applying for jobs as sanitation workers. It's a record turnout of applicants for any city job, officials said Wednesday, and at least one of them thinks he knows why. ``For somebody who likes the outdoors, it's a good, clean living,'' said Sanitation Department spokesman Vito Turso. ``You can build up your muscles, and then get them tanned.'' Sure. But what makes people look at garbage and see gold? Try $23,104 per year to start, with the salary climbing to $35,000 after five years. Add in overtime, and a likely raise with the next city contract, and it's obvious all that smells doesn't necessarily stink. The job requirements are minimal: a driver's license and a strong back. The work week is 35 hours, with the shift running from 7 a.m. to 3 p.m.; summer hours let workers out at 2 p.m. As with most city jobs, there are comprehensive benefits. Negatives? The average city sanitation worker lifts five tons of garbage per day, the rough equivalent of two Toyotas. And the odds of bagging a position are 50-to-1. As of Wednesday, 102,000 people had registered to take the written test this Saturday. Of those who pass, 15,000 will be selected randomly by computer and given the physical test. Eventually, 2,000 will be hired over the next four years, city budgets permitting. Virtually all are expected to pass the written test, which is basically trash-specific. ``It's mostly reading comprehension. They receive manuals on operating the trucks and safety, and the questions deal with that,'' Turso explained. ``For example, which button do you push to start the truck? Button A. Like that.'' When the test was last given in 1983, nearly 95 percent of the 88,000 applicants passed the written part. The physical test is a bit heavier. Potential trash-carriers last time had 27 minutes to load 147 sacks of simulated garbage - 2,975 pounds worth - into a hopper set at the height of a garbage truck. Each applicant has paid a $15 fee to take the written test despite the long odds. Other than that, they might have little in common: the applicants cross all lines of sex and age, with potential employees coming from all walks of life, Turso said. ``We've had individuals come out in their 50s, gray haired, grandchildren in tow,'' said Turso. ``And some of them have actually been called up.''

DOC.HEAD: Russian Parliament Calls For Prime Minister to Quit
DOC.TEXT: The Russian republic's parliament today overwhelmingly approved a resolution urging Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and his Cabinet to resign, calling them unable to save the country from economic ruin. The measure, passed on a 164-1 vote with 16 abstentions, said Ryzhkov's government ``is not capable of pulling the country out of its deep economic crisis.'' The Russian body called on the national parliament, or Supreme Soviet, to ``solve the question of the resignation of the entire government of the USSR.'' The resolution was referring to the Council of Ministers and not President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has backed a sweeping 500-day program that would bring quicker market-oriented reform than Ryzhkov has called for. The Russian parliament last week threw its support behind the 500-day plan. The national Supreme Soviet is now considering whether to approve it or one of two other major proposals. Ryzhkov presented his proposal, the most conservative, to the national body last week. Russia is by far the largest of the country's 15 republics - home to half the Soviet people - and its lawmakers have considerable influence in the national Supreme Soviet, which is to meet Monday. Under Soviet law, the national parliament could call an extraordinary meeting of its parent body, the Congress of Peoples Deputies, which by a two-thirds vote has the right to force the prime minister and his Cabinet out of office. Ryzhkov has been under fire for months amid increasing shortages of basic goods the Communist system has been unable to produce in sufficient quantity. ``The people are living worse each year,'' said Ilya Konstantinov, a Russian parliament lawmaker from Leningrad. ``It's obvious that the Ryzhkov government could not and cannot correct the problem. It's also obvious that the Ryzhkov government is opposed to adopting the radical program of economic reforms,'' he said. The Russian action today came four days after thousands of demonstrators marched in Moscow and demanded Ryzhkov's resignation, citing the failing economy. Many also called for Gorbachev to resign. Ryzhkov has acknowledged publicly that his government will not be able to implement the more radical, 500-day plan, and he indicated he would resign if the national parliament were to vote for it. Ryzhkov's plan envisions continued central control of the economy while gradual moves are made toward a market-based system. The 500-day plan backed by the Russian parliament would return land to private farmers, sell government enterprises to private stockholders and gradually remove state-controlled prices on many goods. It would transfer most economic authority from the central government to the 15 Soviet republics, most of which are pushing for greater sovereignty or independence. Gorbachev has backed a compromise plan that contains many elements of the 500-day blueprint, but would move more slowly and leave the central goverment with strong powers, including the ability to levy taxes in the republics. Ryzhkov, 60, became prime minister in 1985, and he has often been seen in public next to the Soviet leader.

DOC.HEAD: Penn Frats Start BYOB Policy
DOC.TEXT: Fraternities at the University of Pennsylvania, their image tarnished by a series of crimes and pranks, have adopted a ``bring your own booze'' policy for parties. ``We are attempting to take control of a dangerous situation before it takes control of us,'' said Bret Kinsella, a member of Kappa Sigma and president of the Intrafraternity Council. The policy, announced Tuesday, calls for professional doormen at all parties to check that guests are of legal drinking age. Guests cannot bring in more than 12 bottles of beer or an equivalent amount of alcohol. The frat will store the booze and distribute drinks using a ticket system. In recent years, pranks, an alleged gang rape and a kidnapping have hurt the image of the Ivy League school's 31 fraternities. One reason for the new policy, Kinsella said, was increasing liability insurance, ranging from $65 to $350 a year per member. ``We think it is a very responsible action in light of the issues of risk and liability they face,'' said Kim Morrisson, vice provost for university life. But she said, ``There will have to be some further discussion of amounts.'' Bill Epstein, assistant to university President Sheldon Hackney, said 12 beers sounded ``a little on the fluid side.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested For Impersonating High School Cheerleader
DOC.TEXT: A female impersonator enrolled at a high school, made the cheerleading squad and stole the affections of the football team before being found out eight days later, students and authorities said. Charles James Daugherty, 26, was arrested for investigation of forgery and criminal impersonation. He was released on $750 bail for a court appearance Oct. 1. Daugherty enrolled as a junior at Coronado High School, using the name Cheyen Weatherly, school officials said. He said he had been studying in Greece under a private tutor for the past two years, said Detective Bob Driscoll. Daugherty became a cheerleader without a formal tryout and performed in uniform at a pep rally, teachers and students said. He changed clothes in the women's locker room and became close friends with at least two cheerleaders. ``I heard there were a couple of girls who befriended him and told him a lot of personal things - you know how girls talk to one another,'' said one teacher, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``He asked a lot of personal stuff.'' He also attracted the admiration of the football team, said a student who asked that her name not be used. Police said Daugherty presented school officials with a computerized list of courses he had completed and grades to match - all A's and B's. School officials initially were skeptical but allowed him to enroll until more detailed records could be obtained. ``Meanwhile, things started to unravel for him,'' Driscoll said. Daugherty is described as 5-foot-9 and 164 pounds - a build that made teachers and students look twice. School officials increasingly became suspicious and decided to check telephone numbers and addresses Daugherty had provided. Police were called to the school when administrators concluded the information was false. ``This guy's good,'' Driscoll said. ``The school, I think, was pretty astute in catching him as fast as they did.''

DOC.HEAD: Leading Security Council Members Back Air Embargo Proposal
DOC.TEXT: The five permanent members of the Security Council have drafted a resolution that would impose a stiff air embargo on Iraq, prohibiting planes from delivering all but humanitarian cargo. The full 15-member council is expected to vote on the measure Friday or Saturday, diplomats said. It is virtually assured passage because only the five permament members - Britain, France, the United States, Soviet Union and China - have veto power on the council. The resolution says no state shall permit any aircraft of any nation to fly over its territory to or from Iraq or Kuwait, unless the aircraft lands for inspection and possible detention. It does not call for the use of force. The draft resolution also calls for detention of Iraqi-registered ships in foreign ports if they are violating the existing U.N.-ordered embargo on trade. The resolution says all states, despite their international obligations, shall not permit their airlines to operate any scheduled or non-scheduled flights to or from Iraq or Kuwait if they carry cargo other than medical or humanitarian food supplies. It also prohibits any aircraft registered in Iraq or under charter to a national of Iraq to land in foreign territory with unauthorized cargo which is not part of a mercy flight. Diplomats said the language of the resolution was being refined and it still must be considered by the nonaligned and other states before a formal council session. The resolution also warns of further unspecified steps, saying the council is putting the government of Iraq on notice that its continued failure to comply with (Security Council resolutions) will lead the council to take further action under the U.N. Charter ``with potentially severe consequences.'' It confirms that the existing trade embargo approved by the council applies to all means of transport, including aircraft. U.N. officials, meanwhile, said Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar was willing to talk to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad about a peaceful solution to the crisis - but only if the session could be productive. PLO Leader Yassser Arafat has said earlier that Saddam was prepared to negotiate a political solution to the crisis with Perez de Cuellar. Francois Giuliani, the secretary-general's spokesman, said Perez de Cuellar had not been approached by Arafat. ``If he had an invitation to go to Baghdad and felt it would be useful, without raising false expectations and with some indication of flexibility ... then, of course, he is prepared to go.'' The secretary-general on Tuesday expressed frustration about his recent talks in Amman, Jordan, with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. He said he had seen no movement toward dialogue to defuse the crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Both Danger and Hope Seen as Jews Begin High Holidays
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and 8th graf pvs, `The High ...' to fix to High Holidays sted High Holy Days.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Rosh Hashana-Police, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jewish leaders saw both danger and hope on the horizon as they began the High Holidays. Thankfulness was expressed at the crumbling of communism in Eastern Europe and swelling emigration to freedom of Soviet Jews, but there was anxiety over the war clouds in the Middle East. Citing earlier hopeful signs in the world - the loosening of the ``deadly clutch'' of the superpowers and receding of the ``threat of a nuclear holocaust,'' Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler said: ``The guns of August changed all that. Their thunder reminded us that aggression still menaces humankind and that free nations must be ready to resist it.'' Schindler, president of Reform Judaism's Union of American Hebrew Congregations, said Israel ``is at special risk.'' ``Just as anti-Semitism was the cement that bound the Nazi cnspiracy, so does (Iraq's Saddam) Hussein seek to unite the Arab world with his anti-Israel war cries,'' he said. However, he said there is ``one shaft of light in an otherwise gloomy sky'' - that the threat of Iraq will impel other Arab states to join Egypt in reaching an understanding with Israel. The High Holidays, beginning with Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year, on Wednesay night, are marked with synagogue services and prayers of repentance and resolve to do better in the year ahead. The 10-period ends at the close of Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, at sundown Sept. 29. Sholom D. Comay, president of the American Jewish Committee, expressed gratification at the end of the Cold War and moves toward greater democracy. ``But we see also that many old patterns remain,'' he said, including anti-Semitism and dangerous forms of nationalism in Eastern Europe. He urged prayers that the international intervention by East and West and by Arab and non-Arab nations against Saddam would ``succeed and succeed peacefully.'' ``We cannot allow him to hold the world hostage,'' Comay said. In a similar vein, Kent E. Schiner, president of B'nai B'rith International, said that although ``crises are by nature fraught with danger, they also often bring opportunity.'' ``We hope and pray that the changing world order we are witnessing will indeed herald new prospects for peace, security and stability in the Middle East, and especially for our brethren in Israel,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Suspect Claims He Molested Up to 1,000 Children
DOC.TEXT: A man charged with sexually assaulting his 5-year-old grandnephew told investigators he has molested as many as 1,000 children over the last 40 years, police say. George Riley, a 57-year-old handyman, made his claim while being questioned in custody, authorities said Wednesday. He is being held on $1 million bail. Maureen McHale, spokeswoman for the Cook County State's Attorney's office, refused to say whether authorities in the office believed Riley had molested so many children. But she said, ``We will investigate thoroughly any allegation by anyone or any admission by anyone that they have committed'' crimes. Investigators have begun interviewing an unspecified number of people who may have been molested by Riley, Hale said. Riley was picked up Sunday after a witness alleged he saw him molesting a boy in a car parked in suburban Calumet City, said Steven Rhoads, police chief there. He said the victim was Riley's grandnephew. Dante Zorzi, a Calumet City investigator, said he gained Riley's confidence while questioning him. Riley claimed to have molested as many as 1,000 children since he was a teen-ager, police said. ``We do not know if that's exaggeration,'' Rhoads said.

DOC.HEAD: Advice for the Pregnant: Don't Spend More Than 10 Minutes in Hot Tub
DOC.TEXT: Pregnant women who enjoy relaxing in the hot tub shouldn't stay in more than 10 minutes, says a study published today. Too much tub time can raise a woman's body temperature enough to cause malformations in the fetus, said the study, appearing as a letter in the New England Journal of Medicine. According to the latest research, pregnant women should not spend any more than 10 minutes in a tub when the water is 104 degrees. To reach this conclusion, the researchers conducted an experiment on 24 young, non-pregnant women to see how long it takes for their inner-body temperature to reach 102, the point that can be hazardous to the fetus. They found that some people heat up twice as fast as others. In a 104-degree tub, some women's bodies reached 102 in as little as 12 minutes, while others took 23 minutes. They also found that half of the women did not feel uncomfortably hot when their temperatures hit 102. ``We conclude that at least in non-pregnant women, subjective discomfort is not wholly reliable as a safeguard against overheating, and that time limits should also be used,'' the researchers wrote. The study was conducted in Australia by Barry R. Ridge of the University of Western Sydney-Macarthur and Dr. Grahame M. Budd of the National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety in Sydney.

DOC.HEAD: High Keating Bail Caught Prosecutors by Surprise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hearing scheduled to begin at 12:30 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors surprised by a judge's decision to set bail at $5 million for Charles H. Keating Jr. on savings and loan fraud charges agreed to a hearing today on lowering the amount. For District Attorney Ira Reiner and his staff, the high bail set Tuesday by Superior Court Judge Gary Klausner came as something of a shock. In negotiating Keating's surrender, prosecutors told the defense the bail decision would be left to the judge, but they indicated the amount would probably be far lower. ``When the judge set it at $5 million, we were probably as surprised as Mr. Keating,'' said Mike Botula, a Reiner spokesman. Keating and three co-defendants, whose bail was set at $1 million each, remained in jail in the first criminal case stemming from the $2 billion collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan, the nation's biggest S&L failure. They face up to 10 years in prison if convicted. Keating, a 66-year-old developer from Paradise Valley, Ariz., headed Lincoln's parent, American Continental Corp. in Phoenix. The defendants were accused of swindling junk-bond investors by misrepresenting the safety of the investments. All told, more than 20,000 investors are believed to have lost $250 million on the now virtually worthless securities. The judge, in setting bail, said he considered the charges serious. Afterward, posecutors agreed to waive the normal five-day wait before a bail reduction hearing. Keating became a prominent symbol of the nation's S&L scandal because of his lavish personal habits, his risky investments, his political access and the high cost of bailing out Lincoln.

DOC.HEAD: Boarding Home Fire Kills Four; Teen Rescues 10
DOC.TEXT: A high school football player says he dragged or carried 10 people to safety when fire raced through a wooden boarding house for the elderly and infirm, klling four residents. Shawn Bates, 16, said he ran from room to room to evacuate the home early Wednesday but was unable to reach the last four people. ``I thank God for the people I got out and I wish I could have done more for the other people,'' he said. The fire at the one-story home was reported at 2:30 a.m., said fire Capt. Richard Davis. When firefighters arrived, Bates already had rescued 10 of the 15 residents and one woman had escaped on her own. ``Of the four fatalities, two were in wheelchairs and all four were invalids,'' Davis said. One of the dead, William C. Bigham, 31, had been badly burned in a mission fire in Chicago five years ago and ``made me promise if there ever was a fire there, I would get him out. But I couldn't get him out,'' Bates said. Bates said he used to carry Bigham, who suffered from cerebral palsy, wherever he needed to go. The two watched often television together and talked about hunting and fishing. ``I kind of thought I let him down,'' Bates said. ``I believe now he understands. He knows I would have gotten to him if I could have.'' Bates said he was sleeping in the boarding house while visiting his mother, who operates the home and lives next door. He said he was awoken by a fire alarm and when he ran out of his room, he found the fire had been started by an elderly man smoking on a couch. Bates said the man fought with him, but he managed to drag him from the building. Bates was treated for smoke inhalation at Bessemer Carraway Hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down In Tokyo, Stocks Slide
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen in Tokyo today in volatile trading affected by a rumor involving the Persian Gulf crisis, traders said. Share prices fell after a morning rally, sending the Nikkei Stock Average to its lowest closing level in 2{ years. The dollar closed at 137.05 yen, down 1 yen from Wednesday's 138.05-yen finish. It opened at 137.20 yen and ranged between 136.45 yen and 137.40 yen. After opening lower, the U.S. currency fluctuated nervously, influenced by a rumor that Iraq's Saddam Hussein had begun efforts to settle the crisis, dealers said. ``The rumor, initially believed by Japanese investors, temporarily boosted the yen around noon to 136.45 yen per dollar,'' said Eiichi Seino, a dealer with Fuji Bank. ``But the dollar narrowed its losses after the rumor later turned out to be groundless, and discouraged participants started to pick up the U.S. currency again.'' Naohiko Yasuda, a Bank of Tokyo dealer, attributed the dollar's weakness to the yen's strength in cross trading against European currencies. The dollar strengthened earlier this week when investors began selling yen they had overbought in recent weeks, but they once again started buying the Japanese currency, he said. An estimated $12.8 billion traded hands in spot trading. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average fell 123.19 points, or 0.52 percent, ending the day at 23,602.98. The index, which lost 158.65 points on Wednesday, closed at its lowest level since Feb. 3, 1988, when it ended trading at 23,595.37. Trading was thin, with volume on the market's first section estimated at 360 million shares, down from 400 million on Wednesday. The index, which started higher, helped by bargain hunting, erased its early gains when pessimism and uncertainties about the market discouraged investors, traders said. ``Although the Nikkei narrowed its losses early in the afternoon due to the higher yen, it failed to bounce back because of the market's pessimism,'' said Sadayoshi Kiuchi, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. ``We think the market is about to hit bottom, but investors were still reluctant to increase their holdings in an attempt to avoid risks ahead of account settlements for the first half of fiscal 1990,'' he said. The first half of the fiscal year ends Sept. 30 for most Japanese companies. In bond dealings, the yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 8.570 percent, up from Wednesday's close of 8.535 percent. Their price closed at 81.19 points, down from 81.34 Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Man Indicted on Charges of Stealing $1 Million in Animation Cels
DOC.TEXT: A man stole $1 million worth of animation cels from a Warner Bros storage area, including pictures of Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck and Elmer Fudd, prosecutors say. A federal grand jury Tuesday indicted Billy Carmen on charges of interstate transportation of stolen goods. Carmen, 31, of Studio City was accused of shipping 233 cels to out-of-state dealers. He faces up to 30 years in prison and $750,000 in fines. Cels are the plastic, painted overlays used by the thousands to create an animated film. Carmen stole tens of thousands of cels from the storage area in Burbank, Assistant U.S. Attorney Melinda Haag said Wednesday. Carmen had a chocolate shop in the same building, which he left in 1988 without paying rent about the same time the cels disappeared, Ms. Haag said.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Turn Out to Protest at Bush Luncheon
DOC.TEXT: AIDS activists and other demonstrators rattled police barricades, screamed obscenities and hurled bagels and lasagna noodles outside a hotel during a visit by President Bush. Police arrested 85 people. About 500 demonstrators faced off with hundreds of officers in riot gear Wednesday. Police said many in the crowd were anti-war activists protesting the U.S. buildup in the Middle East. But most of those arrested belonged to ACT-Up, the AIDS Coalition To Unleash Power, which accuses Bush of ignoring a commission's recommendation to speed approval of various new drugs, including some for AIDS patients. The commission is headed by Dr. Louis Lasagna - thus, the noodle tossing. The significance of the other food hurled wasn't immediately known. Bush was at the hotel for a $1,500-a-plate fund-raiser for Republican gubernatorial candidate Sen. Pete Wilson, who is locked in a close race with former Mayor Dianne Feinstein. Among the chants were ``Fifteen hundred dollars a plate - AIDS won't wait'' and ``Bush and Quayle belong in jail.'' Protesters were arrested for failure to disperse and unlawful assembly, and were released, police said.
