DOC.HEAD: Evacuees Tell Of Food And Medicine Shortages, Garbage, Rats
With PM-Gulf-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American and other evacuees from Kuwait who arrived in Britain on an Iraqi jet say food and medical supplies are running short in Kuwait, garbage is piled in the streets and rats are a growing problem. A total of 416 evacuees, many of them women and children, arrived on an Iraqi Airways Boeing 747 at Gatwick Airport outside London shortly before midnight. A State Department spokesman in Washington said they included 110 Americans, accompanied by about 200 of their foreign-born family members. Also on the plane, which was chartered by the U.S. government and had flown from Kuwait to Baghdad earlier Wednesday, were 37 Britons and five Canadians. The remaining evacuees on the plane were Jordanians, Egyptians, Palestinians, Icelanders, Spaniards, Greeks, Kenyans and Indonesians. The spokesman said the Americans and their family members, who spent the night in hotels in and around Gatwick, would fly today to Raleigh-Durham, N.C. on another plane chartered by the U.S. government. The British news agency Press Association said Iraqis heading home from Britain were due to join the Iraqi Airways plane at Gatwick for its return flight to Baghdad. Britain on Monday ordered the expulsion of two military attaches and six support staff from the Iraqi Embassy in London and 23 other Iraqis in Britain in retaliation for Iraqi intrusions into some Western embassies in Kuwait. Among those escaping Kuwait was a man who would only give his name as Hassan, who said he was from Salt Lake City and had lived in Kuwait for the last three years. He said: ``Conditions are terrible there. Food and medicine are scarce. There is almost nothing. We have got water but that is about all. ``Kuwait City is dirty. Sickness will probably spread very quickly if nobody cleans the town. Right now they are burning the garbage but the rats are getting really bad.'' He added: ``Kuwait this morning (Wednesday) was calm but we have heard firing, especially at night.'' Heidi Hadi from Layton, Utah who said she had lived in Kuwait for five years, arrived at Gatwick with her 11-month-old son Abdullah. She said her Kuwaiti husband, who worked for the Kuwaiti Interior Ministry, was still there. ``They (the Iraqis) have burned and stolen everything,'' she said. ``They have raped young Kuwaiti girls as young as 14, 15 and 16.'' She said Kuwaiti resistance fighters included both men and women but she said the numbers involved in the fighting against Iraqi troops following the Aug. 2 invasion were small. She said some Iraqi soldiers felt guilty about being in Kuwait. ``There are Iraqis not happy to be there. (These) soldiers, they cry, they grab children and say, `You look like my daughter. I want to go home. I don't want to be here.' ''

DOC.HEAD: Surrogate Fighting for Custody Bears Child Early
DOC.TEXT: A woman who agreed to bear a child for a couple using their egg and sperm gave birth 2{ weeks ahead of schedule, escalating a custody battle that could break new ground over surrogacy. Anna Johnson and the 6-pound, 10-ounce boy were reported in good condition after an uncomplicated delivery Wednesday. Mark and Crispina Calvert, the couple who hired Johnson to carry the baby for $10,000, visited the infant Wednesday night. ``It looks like us,'' Mrs. Calvert said. ``It's got my nose and real straight, brownish hair,'' Calvert said. Months ago, Johnson backed out of the deal and sued the couple for custody. The outcome of the case could be a groundbreaking ruling over what constitutes parenthood - the child's genetic makeup or the act of bearing a child - or a narrow custody decision focused on the child's best interests. Arguments in the case, originally set for Sept. 27, were rescheduled for Friday. Johnson, 29, who knew Mrs. Calvert, 36, from a Santa Ana hospital where they both worked as nurses, claims the couple's enthusiasm for the pregnancy waned. The Calverts did not visit Johnson at St. Joseph's Hospital after the birth but left her a bouquet of red roses. ``It's extremely uplifting,'' said Richard C. Gilbert, Johnson's lawyer. ``Even in the middle of this mess, it's still so exciting. Anna is in heaven.'' William Steiner, the child's legal guardian, ordered hospital officials not to release the baby until a judge decides who will have temporary custody, said Harold F. LaFlamme, the infant's court-appointed lawyer. Under Steiner's orders, the hospital will ``treat the baby as if he has three parents,'' LaFlamme said. Johnson was implanted with an embryo conceived from Crispina's egg and Mark's sperm. Attorneys for the Calverts say she is the first surrogate mother to sue for custody rights even though she has no genetic link to the child she delivered. The case differs from the Baby M case in New Jersey because that child was conceived by a surrogate mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, with the sperm of a man, William Stern, whose wife couldn't have a baby. Whitehead sued for custody of the child and lost. Gilbert said Wednesday his client will agree to a ``shared parenting arrangement'' under which the baby could spend time with Johnson and the Calverts. LaFlamme said he has obtained a court order for immediate DNA testing of the baby to confirm its parentage. Johnson's attorneys have raised the possibility that the embryo implant did not take and the baby is hers genetically. Johnson calls the child Matthew. Nurses at the Orange hospital call him Baby Boy Johnson. Mrs. Calvert said she and her husband want to name the child Michael Christian. ``I'm real excited, but I'm also worried,'' Mrs. Calvert said. ``I know in my heart that he's our bab, but there's still the question, what if we don't win? What if we don't get him?''

DOC.HEAD: Two Masked Men Break Into Iraqi Ambassador's Residence
DOC.TEXT: Police were searching today for two masked men who broke into the Iraqi ambassador's residence, ransacked his private office and knocked an employee unconscious, a police spokesman said. The spokesman said no arrests had been made and it was not clear if any files or documents were missing from the house. He spoke on condition of anonymity. The diplomat could not confirm whether the ambassador kept official documents in the office, the police spokesman said. Although the break-in looked like a simple burglary, political motives cannot be ruled out, he said. The two men entered the villa of Ambassador Rahim Abid Alkital in Vienna's Hernals district on Wednesday afternoon. They slipped by police guards, cut through a barbed wire fence and forced a window, police said. They clubbed unconscious a 26-year-old Sri Lankan employee at the residence who saw them entering. They then ransacked the ambassador's office and a neighboring room before escaping, the spokesman said. The ambassador's wife found the unidentified employee when she returned to the residence at 6:30 p.m. The employee was tied up and suffering from a concussion, the police spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia Gives Lebanon $100 Million
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia has given Lebanon $100 million to help it cope with the civil war-ravaged economy that was aggravated by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, a government statement said today. Saudi Arabia informed Prime Minister Salim Hoss on Wednesday night that Saudi King Fahd personally ordered the cash transfer to the Lebanese Central Bank, the statement said. A government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said ``the gift was a tranquilizer,'' which will help avoid a further deterioration of the economic situation, but not resolve the problem. ``It will definitely help rebuild some sort of confidence for the future,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Iraqi invasion sabotaged plans for a $2 billion Arab fund to shore up a Lebanese economy wracked by 15 years of sectarian fighting that has claimed 130,000 lives. Contributors were to be the oil-rich countries of the Persian Gulf, including Kuwait. But after Iraq's Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait, focus shifted away from Lebanon as Saudi Arabia and its gulf Arab neighbors began channeling money to help Kuwaiti refugees and finance multinational forces massing up against Iraq. The Lebanese pound plunged to a record low of 1,200 pounds to the dollar in recent days. It sold for 600 to the dollar before the gulf crisis. The prices of commodities have tripled or quadrupled over the last two weeks. The government-decreed minimum wage of 45,000 Lebanese pounds a month is now worth $40 compared to more than $80 in late July. Lebanon's deficit of the 1990 fiscal year was estimated at $50 million. The dollar marked a slow decline against the pound today, opening at 1,100 pounds to the dollar in the money market. The Lebanese pound was one of the soundest Middle Eastern currencies before the outbreak of its civil war between Moslems and Christians in 1975. It traded at 2.5 pounds to the dollar. President Elias Hrawi last week appealed to Fahd to spearhead an Arab campaign aimed at providing Lebanon with urgent aid to ward off ``the dangers of starvation and poverty threatening the Lebanese society.'' The Arab League's trouble-shooter, Lakhdar Ibrahimi, an Algerian, has been campaigning in the Arab world and Europe to add Lebanon to the list of countries hardest-hit by the gulf crisis, which now includes Egypt, Jordan and Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Dives Against Yen, Gold Up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued to sink against the Japanese yen in European trading this morning and was mixed against other key currencies. Gold was down slightly. In Tokyo the dollar closed at 137.05 yen, down 1.00 yen from Wednesday's 138.05-yen finish. Later in London it was quoted at 136.80 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: -1.5700 German marks, up from 1.5680 -1.3080 Swiss francs, up from 1.3055 -5.2615 French francs, up from 5.2515 -1.7720 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7670 -1,171.00 Italian lire, down from 1,172.50 -1.1538 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1575 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8765, compared with $1.8855 late Wednesday. In Tokyo the dollar fluctuated nervously, influenced by a rumor that Iraq's Saddam Hussein had begun efforts to settle the Persian Gulf crisis, dealers said. ``The rumor, initially believed by Japanese investors, temporarily boosted the yen around noon to 136.45 yen per dollar,'' said Eiichi Seino, a dealer with Fuji Bank. ``But the dollar narrowed its losses after the rumor later turned out to be groundless, and discouraged participants started to pick up the U.S. currency again.'' Naohiko Yasuda, a Bank of Tokyo dealer, attributed the dollar's weakness to the yen's strength in cross-trading against European currencies. The dollar strengthened earlier this week when investors began selling yen they had overbought in recent weeks, but they once again started buying the Japanese currency, he said. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $386.00 per ounce at midmorning, down from $386.75 bid per ounce late Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $386.70, up from $385.50 late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped 44 cents an ounce today, to close at $384.91. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.80 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $4.82.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait's Invasion Worsens Lebanon's Plight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf ``The invasion...'' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Saudis giving $100 million to Lebanon. Pickup 8th graf `The prices...'
DOC.TEXT: Younis Bazzi climbed a cliff in Beirut overlooking the Mediterranean last week and flung himself onto the rocks below. He was Lebanon's first fatality in the gulf crisis. Bazzi, 45, a Shiite Moslem cab driver, left a note on the cliff along with the identity cards of his four children: Imad, 13, Ilham, 11, Fatima, 9 and Yousef, 6. ``I can't cope any more. I can't feed even you, let alone send you to school,'' the note said. ``I've decided to end my agony. Good luck to all of you and please forgive me.'' Bazzi's death was a dramatic example of how Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait has caused more economic and social hardship in a country already ravaged by 15 years of civil war. President Elias Hrawi's government was counting on $2 billion in reconstruction aid pledged by the oil-rich Arab nations of the Persian Gulf to help shore up the Lebanese economy. ``This hope has been buried in Kuwait's sands,'' said a commentator on Beirut's Voice of the People radio station. ``No one can expect anyone in the Arabian peninsula to show concern for Lebanon. They're preoccupied with the Iraqi threat on their doorstep.'' Today, the government said Saudi Arabia gave it $100 million. A government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said ``the gift was a tranquilizer,'' which will help avoid a further deterioration of the economic situation, but not resolve the problem. The invasion of Kuwait sent the Lebanese currency tumbling to a record low - from 600 pounds to the dollar in late July to 1,100 pounds to the dollar now. The prices of commodities have tripled or quadrupled over the last two weeks. A loaf of bread costs 10 cents, five times what it cost early last month. The worldwide surge in oil prices triggered by the crisis has been devastating. Lebanon imports all its oil and is now paying double what it was six weeks ago with foreign currency it can ill afford. It's the same story with such staples as rice, sugar, vegetables, potatoes, milk and canned food. Lebanon has to import more than 90 percent of its food. The minimum wage of 45,000 Lebanese pounds a month is now worth $40, compared to more than $80 in late July. ``My salary's barely enough to support my wife and two kids for one day, let alone a whole month,'' lamented Mahmoud Safi, 30, a minimum-wage bus driver. Economists say that the gulf crisis has done as much damage to the economy, once the most prosperous in the Middle East, as the 15 years of civil war, Israeli invasions and factional feuding put together. Frantic pleas by Hrawi and Prime Minister Salim Hoss to have Lebanon listed as a hard-hit victim of the gulf crisis so it can qualify for international compensation have fallen on deaf ears. In a recent message to Western heads of state, Hrawi said some 50,000 Lebanese who had been working in Kuwait and sending home about $200 million a month are now broke. One of them, H. Zahreddin, a wealthy businessman, flew to Beirut on Aug. 1 to throw a wedding party for his daughter at a posh beachside hotel. ``I went to bed a millionaire and woke up in debt,'' Zahreddin said the next day. ``The hotel refused to accept my Kuwaiti dinar check to settle the party bill.'' Another Lebanese resident of Kuwait, Mahmoud Kurdi, drove from Kuwait to spend his summer vacation at home in the ancient city of Baalbek in east Lebanon. He crossed the Syrian border into Lebanon on Aug. 1 and stopped at the market town of Chtaura to cash a bank check of 50,000 Kuwaiti dinars, roughly $200,000. When money-changers there demanded what he considered an unreasonably high exchange commission, Kurdi decided to cash his check for a better rate in Beirut the next day. ``But the next day Saddam Hussein wiped me out,'' Kurdi moaned. ``My check's now a worthless piece of paper.'' The currency crisis boomeranged on business. Banks in Beirut have stopped changing dollar checks, offering only to pay the equivalent in Lebanese pounds. Nightlife that was just starting to pick up again after recent fighting has come to a virtual standstill. Discotheques and restaurants are empty. The fun-loving partygoers who defied the worst civil war shelling in the last two years are staying home. ``They just can't afford to go out any more,'' said barman Habib Naimeh, who runs the Megalith, one of Beirut's most frequented pubs.

DOC.HEAD: Savannah River Operator Says Reactor Restart May Be Delayed
DOC.TEXT: The operator of the Savannah River nuclear arms plant has uncovered up to 2,000 problems in one of the three reactors that could delay the year-end deadline for restarting operations, an official said. Westinghouse Savannah River Co., which runs the plant for the government, has discovered the faults since mid-August, said Energy Department Assistant Secretary Steve Richardson. ``It's like taking your car in and the mechanic really starts working on it and finds more things wrong,'' Richardson said. ``Those things were not anticipated in the schedule, there was no way you could.'' The plant, in South Carolina across the Savannah River from Augusta, has been shut down since August 1988 because of safety concerns. Westinghouse, which assumed control of the plant from Du Pont in April 1989, did not specify the nature of the latest problems. Westinghouse and Energy Department officials will recommend to Energy Secretary James D. Watkins within three weeks whether to delay the restart, Richardson said. ``It's too early to tell whether we would recommend any schedule changes,'' said Westinghouse spokesman Bruce Cadotte said. ``We are still going through the analysis with the Department of Energy.'' In May, Watkins said the reactor would begin low-power testing in December and start producing materials for nuclear weapons later that month or early in January. The other two reactors would begin production by October 1991, he said. The Savannah River reactors are the sole producers of tritium, a radioactive gas used to boost the explosive power of nuclear weapons. Because it decays 5.5 percent annually, tritium-loaded warheads must be periodically replenished.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Depression Drifts Westward in mid-Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: The 11th tropical depression of the Atlantic hurricane season continued its westward drift in the mid-Atlantic, and forecasters expected little change in strength for the system during the next 24 hours. At 6 a.m. EDT, the depression's center was located near 15.9 north latitude and 49.9 west longitude, or about 700 miles east of the Lesser Antilles, according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. The depression, packing top sustained winds of 35 mph, was moving westward at less than 5 mph. That motion was expected to continue today and Friday with some increase in forward speed and a gradual turn likely toward the northwest. Tropical depressions become tropical storms when their maximum winds reach 39 mph.
