DOC.HEAD: Dallas Official Refuses to Apologize for His `Call to Arms'
DOC.TEXT: Any violence that might erupt in a city with strained relations between police and its minorities would only be defensive, says a county commissioner who had issued a ``call to arms.'' Commissioner John Wiley Price, who warned violence would result if the city hires a ``good old boy'' police chief who's insensitive to minorities, told a news conference Wednesday evening he was clarifying - but not apologizing for - the remarks. ``And so I say to you today that the call to arms is not an offensive move - it's not a move of aggression,'' Price said. ``We will say we will defend our community; historically, we had to defend our community and we will continue to defend our community. ``That does not mean that we are going to be aggressive in going after police officers in this community. But we are saying to you that we must defend our community at all costs.'' Price had made the earlier remarks in an interview published Wednesday in The Dallas Morning News. ``If you try to bring in a good old boy in this system, we're going to be in the streets. Physically, literally, shooting folks. We're not going to tolerate it,'' the Dallas County commissioner said in Wednesday's article. He later softened his remarks and told the newspaper he would advocate violence against police only in the event of officers' violence against civilians. The Dallas County district attorney's office said it was investigating the legal implications, if any, of Price's statements on violence. Prosecutors said they had received more than 100 telephone calls about the statements Wednesday. ``There is a fine line between what is constitutionally protected free speech and what is not,'' said Ted Steinke, an assistant district attorney. ``We are attempting to determine whether Commissioner Price's words have actually crossed that line.'' At the news conference, Price said his statements quoted by the newspaper were irresponsible and may have been inflammatory. ``I don't want anyone to take what I say and take it to the streets,'' he said. ``At this particular time, taking it to the streets is inappropriate behavior.'' He said he was saddened by the firing this month of Chief Mack Vines, hired in 1988 to mend relations with minorities that were strained, mostly over a record number of police shootings of blacks and Hispanics. Vines was accused of lying to a special panel investigating the firing of officer Patrick LeMaire, who fatally shot an unarmed Mexican national last year. Black and Hispanic leaders had demanded LeMaire be fired. ``There are a number of our friends who are Dallas police officers,'' Price told reporters. ``I was called by them and they had some concerns on my remarks. I assured them that in no way do we plan any kind of assault on the Dallas Police Department, organized or otherwise, at this moment.'' Police spokesman Bill Bateman said the department issued a ``chief's update'' on Wednesday warning officers to be on the alert and to be responsible if they made comments to the press. ``I do not think we should do anything in this city that polarizes the city and creates a hostile environment,'' Mayor Annette Strauss said of Price's statements. City councilwoman Harriet Miers said she hoped churches and other community organizations would ``let this city know that they don't like to be threatened and they don't like blackmail and this kind of behavior is totally unacceptable.''

DOC.HEAD: Parents Sue over Mandatory Community Service In Schools
DOC.TEXT: A group of parents is suing a school system over its new program requiring students to perform 60 hours of volunteer work. ``I don't want my son being told what to do,'' said Thomas Moralis, one of the plaintiffs, whose son David is in the Bethlehem Area School District. ``I went to school in a free America, and I want the same for my children.'' Moralis and his wife and two other parents filed suit Wednesday in U.S. District Court against the school board, which approved the program last spring. The lawsuit seeks to end the program and asks that the defendants pay for legal costs. Students are required to work 60 hours, which can be spread over four years. They choose where they will work from a list approved last week by the school board. School board members defended the program. ``I think it is good for our kids,'' said board member John Spirk, adding that the city solicitor told the board the program was legal. ``The administration researched it, and found it something our kids ought to be working on,'' he said. The parents' lawyer, Robert J. Magee, said the school board used a similar program in Atlanta as a model, but the high school dropout rate in Atlanta has increased since the program started. The lawsuit said the program was ``inconsistent with certain values and standards'' the parents hold and it questions the program's safety. Thomas and Barbara Moralis were joined in the suit by Thomas and Barbara Steirer, whose daughter Lynn Ann is a student. The parents are members of a 21-family organization called Citizens Against Mandatory Service Inc., which is sponsoring the suit. Moralis opposes the choice of organizations, including a religious group and a hospital operating room, and said the students may have to pay a fee to join one group or to buy a uniform. ``Some can't afford this,'' he said. Moralis said he does not oppose community service. ``The school administration said that they don't care if they perform community service ever again after they graduate,'' Moralis added. ``It's destroying whatever good will and helpful attitude there existed in the community.''

DOC.HEAD: US Offers to Reduce Troop Strength in Philippines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 18 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. offer to reduce troop strength, new quotes. Pickup 16th graf pvs, `The government ...'
DOC.TEXT: The United States today offered to reduce its troop strength in the Philippines but expressed hope it could maintain a military presence ``which both countries would judge appropriate.'' U.S. negotiators made the offer during the third day of talks on the future of Clark Air Base, Subic Bay naval base and four smaller installations, whose lease expires in September 1991. Philippine negotiators said they wanted to take operational control of Clark as soon as possible, although the proposed timetable was unclear. Philippine spokesman Rafael Alunan said the government was waiting for a U.S. counterproposal. U.S. spokesman Stanley Schrager told reporters that the American team, led by chief negotiator Richard Armitage, outlined its proposals for a military presence after 1991. ``We would hope that the relationship would continue with appropriate U.S. access to and use of the Philippine facilities, together with a U.S. military presence, which both countries would judge appropriate to meet our needs,'' Schrager said. The discussions were to continue Friday. Alunan said the talks were expected to be adjourned then to an undetermined date. Earlier today, Alunan said President Corazon Aquino would order the dismantling of the six U.S. military bases unless U.S.-Philippine talks produce an agreement by January. ``If there is no treaty or arrangement, let's say by January, ... then we will most likely create a committee that will oversee the dismantling of the base,'' Alunan said. ``It is important for us to have a treaty or an arrangement,'' he said in a radio interview. ``If there is no understanding, nothing will come of the bases such that by Sept. 16, 1991, they will have to leave.'' The United States maintains 40,000 troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents at the six bases. The bases are technically under Philippine control but are effectively run by the Americans, who ruled this nation from 1898 until independence in 1946. Mrs. Aquino said on the eve of the talks that the time had come for an orderly withdrawal of the bases, the oldest and largest American overseas installations. Any treaty to keep the bases after the lease runs out requires approval by two-thirds of the 23-member Senate, where opposition is strong. The Philippine Congress could also require the extension to be approved in a national referendum. Opponents, such as Communist rebels, believe the bases infringe on national sovereignty. In Washington, the State Department warned Americans in the Philippines of ``a possible imminent terrorist bombing'' by the communist New People's Army against U.S. government or other public facilities in Manila. A brief statement attributed to spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the danger was greatest ``in the vicinity of Roxas Boulevard,'' where the U.S. Embassy is located and where talks on the future of the six U.S. military bases in the Philippines were being held. American civilians said they were contacted by the embassy today and advised of the alleged threat. In a related development, the Aquino government handed out a 10-page pamphlet today to the news media that sought to minimize the bases' political and economic importance. The government primer on the bases says the bases are not needed to prevent the overthrow of the government. In December, U.S. jets from Clark flew air cover for loyal troops during a coup attempt that claimed more than 100 lives. Later, the government belittled the American role in saving Mrs. Aquino. The bases' contribution to the economy in 1990 will amount to ``only 1.9 percent'' of the gross national product, the pamphlet says. The bases have created jobs for 130,000 Filipinos. The facilities generate child prostitution, AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases, abandoned Amerasian children, drug addition and dislocation of tribespeople from their ancestral lands, according to the pamphlet. But the pamphlet says that even if the bases are closed, the Philippines will still be ``committed to continue the friendship the country has had with the U.S. for decades.''

DOC.HEAD: Surgeons Work To Save Maimed Toddler
DOC.TEXT: A 2-year-old boy who had ``almost every square inch'' of his body mauled by a pack of dogs was breathing with a respirator today and in critical condition. Steven Selfridge of Saxonburg was attacked by six Rottweilers while playing with a cousin Tuesday at his grandmother's Butler County home. Surgeons spent eight hours Wednesday reconstructing the boy's windpipe, one lung, veins and arteries. Another 4{ hours were needed for plastic surgery on his head, face and neck. The dog bites caused massive blood loss and Steven's face was maimed, said Dr. Max Ramenofsky of Allegheny Hospital. The injuries were so severe paramedics were unable to find a vein solid enough for inserting an intravenous needle, he said. Rottweilers are known for their strong jaw and thick neck muscles. ``Steven had almost every square inch of his body bit or torn,'' said Dr. Max Ramenofsky of Allegheny General. Doctors today watched for signs of infection and said it was too early to offer opinions on Steven's recovery. The boy's 11-year-old cousin, Jamie Ross, threw herself into the pack but was unable to keep the dogs away from Steven, police said. She then called police. ``She's the real hero here,'' said Chris Jones, a paramedic who was the first to arrive at the scene. ``At one point she tried to cover the little boy with her body.'' Jones eventually dispersed the pack with short bursts from a carbon dioxide fire extinguisher. The attack lasted at least 10 minutes, Officer John Draper said. Jamie was treated for cuts and bruises and released Tuesday from Butler Memorial Hospital. The dogs were kept at the house under a 15-day quarantine order by the township's dog officer. ``Destroying the dogs will be up to the courts,'' Butler Township Police Chief Gary Garman said.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Moves Out to Sea After Leaving 38 Dead in Japan
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Flo swept into the Pacific Ocean today after flooding tens of thousands of homes and roads, causing landslides and leaving at least 38 people dead or missing, police said. A full night and morning of heavy rains caused flooding and landslides in western and northern Japan before the typhoon headed out to sea off the coast of Iwate prefecture. The typhoon's three-day rampage through Japan left at least 29 people dead, nine missing and 90 injured, police said. They said 11 of the victims died in a landslide Tuesday night on Amami island in southern Japan. Television stations showed scenes of devastation from throughout the country, including village streets deep in muddy water, overturned vehicles and washed out roads. The NTV network showed one man in Gifu prefecture using a shovel to propel a makeshift rowboat made from a box through a flooded street. The typhoon had up to 101 mph winds when it landed in southwestern Wakayama prefecture, but lost strength as it moved throughout the archipelago. The Japan Broadcasting Corp. said damage was reported in 44 of the island nation's 47 prefectures. The storm brought high winds and some rain to Tokyo late Wednesday, but the capital escaped largely unscathed. Police said the storm triggered 557 landslides, washed away 31 bridges and washed away or sank 68 boats. Ninety-five homes and buildings were destroyed, and another 181 were badly damaged, police said. Nearly 27,000 buildings were flooded. The typhoon flooded or cut roads at 418 locations and railroads at 31 spots. Airlines canceled 62 flights today and numerous trains also were canceled or delayed, police said. The typhoon was one of the most powerful storms to hit Japan in recent years. It was nearly as strong as a 1961 typhoon that left nearly 5,000 people killed and injured, according to Takatoshi Higuchi of the Fire Defense Agency. ``We were lucky because the typhoon somewhat lost its strength ... when it landed,'' Higuchi said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Threatens to Destroy Oil Fields if Attacked
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq will knock out Persian Gulf oil fields if attacked by U.S.-led multinational forces in Saudi Arabia, a senior Iraqi official said in a statement published today. ``Iraq's strategic plan, if it is attacked militarily, is to destroy all oil fields in the region,'' Information Minister Latif Nassayef Jassim said. He added: ``Iraq will use all weapons at its disposal to respond to any aggression'' that might be launched to force its occupation force to relinquish Kuwait. His remarks were published by the English-language daily Jordan Times. The newspaper said Jassim made the threat to a group of Jordanian journalists who visited Iraq this week. He said Iraq's ``strategic aim is to free Palestine,'' echoing Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's effort to negotiate simultaneous settlements for his occupation of Kuwait and the Palestinian problem to project himself as the unrivaled leader of the Arab world. Western officials have expressed fears that Iraq might be plotting a campaign of sabotage. CIA Director William H. Webster said Tuesday that Iraq's terrorist capabilities, chemical weapons and missiles pose a serious international threat. What is difficult to determine, he said, is whether Saddam would use these capabilities in the gulf standoff. Other Iraqi officials also have said their military would deploy all weapons in case the forces in Saudi Arabia attacked Iraq to reverse its Aug. 2 occupation of Kuwait. Iraq is known to possess chemical weapons, which it used in the 1980-88 war against Iran. In 1988, Saddam used chemical weapons against his own people while crushing a rebellion by the ethinic Kurdish minority in northern Iraq. Thousands of people were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Students Clash With Police in Anti-Government Protests
DOC.TEXT: Students hurled rocks and firebombs at police today during demonstrations demanding the government dissolve the National Assembly and resist U.S. pressure for greater farm imports. The clashes between police and about 1,500 protesters at Seoul's Konkook University were among several anti-government rallies around the nation today. No arrests or injuries were reported. Protesters claim a merger of the governing party and two other parties in the legislature is designed to perpetuate the rule of President Roh Tae-woo. In August, all 78 opposition members of the assembly resigned in protest. The rallies also urged South Korea to reject proposals to liberalize imports of agricultural products. They claim the proposals, backed by the United States, would bring in cheaper foreign farm products and threaten South Korean farmers. At Konkook University, police fired tear gas from armored vans to drive the students back inside buildings. In the southern city of Kwangju, 5,000 riot police sealed off a plaza in front of the provincial government building to block a rally, said the national news agency Yonhap. About 200 students attacked a police substation in Kwangju with firebombs, but there was no damage reported, Yonhap said. About 1,500 students clashed with police in a two-hour battle outside Chonnam University in Kwangju, and another 1,000 students confronted police outside Chosun University, the agency reported. Protests were also staged in the southern cities of Mokpo and Sunchon, Yonhap said.

DOC.HEAD: Noted Sports Columnist, 78 Others Opt to Quit New York Post
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to restore AP bug.
DOC.TEXT: Noted sports columnist Peter Vecsey and 78 other New York Post employees will leave the newspaper under a buyout plan that was part of a $19 million union concession package designed to keep the paper alive. The Newspaper Guild resignations, which were voluntary, mean the Post will lose close to 200 of its 960 workers. Agreements reached last week called for 100 forced resignations from the 263-member drivers union and five from the Post's 17 paper handlers. All are to receive the same buyout package, which includes full severance and an extra eight weeks pay they would have been entitled to if the paper had closed. Post Editor Jerry Nachman said about half of the Guild resignations were from the newsroom, which translates to about a third of the news staff. ``It's not a number I like, or I'm happy with,'' he said. The newspaper had sought only 43 resignations from the Guild - plus a 20 percent pay cut - to keep the paper running. But owner Peter Kalikow agreed in a last-minute compromise to accept however many voluntary resignations were tendered. Anyone choosing to resign by 5 p.m. Wednesday would get the same termination and severance pay as if the paper had closed. The Guild resignations included people from editorial, advertising, circulation, and accounting, although a breakdown by department was not immediately available. The total cost of the 79 resignations to the Post was being tabulated, Post spokesman Howard Rubinstein said. ``Some highly talented individuals have elected to depart,'' Post spokesman Howard Rubinstein said. But, he added, Kalikow ``is extremely confident that they will continue to turn out an exciting newspaper that will have a major impact on the city.'' Thomas Pennacchio, Guild secretary-treasurer, said the newspaper most likely would have to hire more people to replace any overabundance of buyouts. ``The sense is that some people want to leave because they can't afford the 20 percent cut,'' Pennachio said. ``Some are leaving because they think the Post won't last long.'' The Guild had been the holdout among 11 unions that gave Kalikow more than $19 million in concessions he demanded from them to eliminate his $27 million worth of annual red ink. Vecsey, whose gossipy, acerbic column was closely followed by fans of professional basketball, will begin a sports column at USA Today on Oct. 1. Post vice president Peter Faris said Vecsey's contract expires in November and the Post did not match other offers he received. He said Vecsey's resignation was ``divorced from the buyout scenario although as a Guild member he is availing himself of the opportunity.'' Vecsey also recently signed to be a reporter on NBC's NBA pregame show, ``The Insiders.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Spy Chief Willing To Give CIA Intelligence Data on Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to restore second K in Kryuchkov.
DOC.TEXT: The KGB would like to exchange information with the CIA on Iraq but has not made the offer directly because past proposals for cooperation have been rebuffed, the spy agency's chief has told The Associated Press. ``I am convinced that we could really tell each other something valuable, especially about ensuring the security of Soviet and American citizens'' in the Persian Gulf region, KGB chairman Vladimir A. Kryuchkov said in an interview. If the CIA wants help, ``You can be sure that our reaction would be positive,'' Kryuchkov told the visiting AP board of directors and executives on Wednesday. He said his agency is also willing to work with U.S. intelligence in fighting international terrorism and narcotics trafficking. The balding, white-haired Kryuchkov sat beneath a portrait of Soviet founder Vladimir I. Lenin. Beside the KGB chief was a vase of bright flowers that contrasted with the stark decor of the wood-paneled conference room on the third floor of the Lubyanka, the gray, pink and yellow KGB headquarters in downtown Moscow. On his left hung a portrait of Felix Dzerzhinsky, founder of the Soviet secret police. He joked with the group about the fear the KGB and the Lubyanka inspired but said in serious tones that the agency was leaving behind that ``tragic page'' of history. In meetings with American officials, Kryuchkov said, ``we always give signals about being ready to work together in this or that field'' with U.S. intelligence. ``The signals reach the right address,'' he said, but the answer is always something along the lines of, ``We are not ready yet.'' It was not clear precisely what sort of information the Soviets might be willing to offer the United States. Most Iraqi military equipment is Soviet-made, and providing intelligence on how to defeat that equipment in battle might undermine the effectiveness of the Soviet military in any possible confrontation with the United States. Moreover, Kryuchkov acknowledged, the Kremlin is concerned about possible Iraqi actions against Soviets who remain in that country. The Soviet Union still has about 5,000 specialists in Iraq, Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said in a separate briefing. ``We used to have about 8,000 experts,'' including non-military specialists, he said. ``We said that we evacuated children and women ... which is not exactly correct. We evacuated spouses and children. There are some women experts still there. So far, 2,500 persons left Iraq, all the children, all the spouses,'' he said. ``The Soviet community is slightly more than 5,000. About 60 of them are women, these are experts of different Soviet establishments there, say, typists,'' said Gerasimov. ``The experts whose contracts expire leave the country using Aeroflot regular flights,'' he said, referring to the Soviet government airline. ``Iraqi authorities did not make any impediments to that.'' Kryuchkov, in his interview with the AP, also denied that the Soviet government had planted electronic eavesdropping devices in the new U.S. Embassy office building in Moscow. U.S. officials have accused the KGB of lacing the brick structure with sophisticated bugging devices. The Bush administration is weighing plans to destroy the structure and build another at a cost of tens of millions of dollars. Kryuchkov said he envisioned the day when the two superpowers would no longer spy on each other. Already, he said, ``We do not consider the United States of America our main enemy.'' In the interview, Kryuchkov also said he did not want to see the KGB divided into foreign and domestic intelligence-gathering operations, along the lines of the FBI and CIA. He declined to disclose the KGB budget or the number of agents it employs, citing similar secrecy on the part of U.S. intelligence. The Supreme Soviet parliament is drafting a law that would govern the actions of the KGB and give a legislative commission the right to learn all the agency's secrets, similar to the Select Intelligence Committees in the U.S. Congress, he said. Already, he said, the Ministry of Finance has a special department that monitors the agency's expenditures.

DOC.HEAD: Study: No Evidence Beta Carotene Prevents Skin Cancer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf, `A separate . . .' with 2 grafs to ADD background of when Accutane report was widely publicized.
DOC.TEXT: Scientists today said big doses of the nutrient beta carotene fail to prevent skin cancer but that Mom's advice still holds: Eat your vegetables. People who eat plenty of fruits and vegetables are less likely to get cancer, and experts had suspected that their intake of beta carotene might explain this. But a study published today in the New England Journal of Medicine found that beta carotene does not seem to be the key ingredient, at least as far as skin cancer is concerned. ``This conclusion should not, however, deter people from eating fruits and vegetables,'' the researchers wrote. Beta carotene is the nutrient that makes carrots yellow and is found in varying degrees in many fruits and vegetables. The body uses it to manufacture vitamin A, which some believe can prevent cancer, perhaps by trapping chemical compounds known as free radicals that can harm the body's cells. The researchers tested beta carotene pills on people who had been treated for basal-cell or squamous-cell skin cancer. None had melanoma, the far more dangerous malignant form of skin cancer. The treatment did nothing to slow the growth of new skin cancers. ``Although our results provide no support for an anti-cancer effect of oral beta carotene on non-melanoma skin cancer, it would be unwise to conclude on the basis of this study alone that beta carotene is ineffective against all cancers,'' the researchers wrote. They noted other evidence to suggest that it might prevent lung cancer. Several other studies of beta carotene are also under way. The study was directed by Dr. E. Robert Greenberg of Dartmouth Medical School. In the study, 1,805 people were randomly assigned to take 50 milligrams of beta carotene or placebos each day for a year. After five years of follow-up, 362 people who took beta carotene and 340 in the comparison group had at least one new skin cancer. The researchers concluded that there is not enough evidence to prescribe the nutrient as an anti-cancer treatment. A separate study in the journal, by Dr. Waun K. Hong of M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, showed that the acne drug Accutane blocked the growth of new tumors in people being treated for smoking-related cancer of the mouth and throat. The report was widely publicized in May when it was presented in Washington at a meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology. Even after this cancer is initially removed, patients risk getting new tumors elsewhere in their throats and lungs. Accutane, an artificial form of vitamin A, reduced the recurrence rate from 24 percent in untreated patients to 4 percent in those getting the medicine.

DOC.HEAD: Conferees Begin Work With 15 Percent Wheat ARP
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 2nd and 3rd grafs to UPDATE with USDA announcement
DOC.TEXT: The House-Senate conference committee working on the 1990 farm bill set acreage reduction for wheat at 15 percent this crop year as its first action toward melding the bills each body approved this summer. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter announced today a 15 percent acreage set-aside for the 1991 wheat crop. Previously, he had said it was his intention to require a reduction of 10 percent to 20 percent. Yeutter said he was pleased that the conferees ``acted so quickly on this important issue for winter wheat growers,'' who are now planting their 1991 crop. The vote came Wednesday at the urging of the Agriculture Department, which needs to advise farmers planting winter wheat on the requirements they must follow to participate in the government's subsidy programs. It followed an exchange of formalities between the chd food exports apparently to ensure the country has adequate supplies this winter. Leading members of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces have said that the Socialists would not meet their demands for participating in the Cabinet. The opposition seeks immediate privatization of land and industry, and return of land to those who owned it before it was collectivized under Communist rule. The Socialists agree to land reform, but say land should be given to those who are tilling it now. Lukanov's Cabinet contained only a handful of new faces, but included the first new defense minister in 28 years. Lukanov replaced Dobri Dzhurov with Yordan Mutafchiev. Dzhurov was a close associate of former Communist Party chief Todor Zhivkov but was credited with helping party reformers remove the hard-line leader in November. Science Minister Ilya Konev is the only Cabinet member not associated with the Socialist Party. Two others, Labor and Social Welfare Minister Emilia Maslarova, and Culture Minister Dimo Dimov, are not formally members of the Socialist Party but were endorsed by the Socialists when they ran for parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Reportedly Will Visit U.S. Troops at Thanksgiving
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is planning to visit U.S. soldiers in the Persian Gulf at Thanksgiving, about the same time he intends to go to Europe and Latin America, a newspaper reported today. Quoting unidentified administration officials, Newsday said tentative plans called for Bush to make a morale-building appearance among the troops of Operation Desert Shield in Saudi Arabia and possibly stop in Egypt and Turkey to thank their leaders for cooperating against Iraq. In Washington, White House officials said they could not confirm the report and that no travel plans have been set. Thanksgiving was seen by White House advisers as a better time than Christmas for Bush's visit because it is a secular American holiday and less likely to upset Saudi Arabia's conservative Moslem leadership, Newsday said. The visit would be part of a trip that tentatively would start in Prague, Czechoslovakia, and include the Nov. 19 Paris summit of the 34 nations in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The president then would visit Mexico Nov. 28-29 and make a six-day trip in South America the first week of December, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Officials: Sign May Not Have Triggered Deadly Wall Collapse
DOC.TEXT: City officials say no evidence exists that a large sign was to blame for the collapse of a downtown building's wall that killed three people. City officials and police initially blamed a large metal sign on the front of the Any Kind Check Cashing Agency for Tuesday's collapse, which also injured eight people. But Cynthia Bayete, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Licenses and Inspections, told The Philadelphia Inquirer in today's editions it appears now signs were not to blame. ``The feeling is that the signs did not have anything to do with'' the collapse, Bayete said. The department's commissioner, Don Kligerman, said earlier that the collapse apparently was triggered by the metal sign and steel security gates, which he said were improperly fastened to the wall. He said the two-story building's owners were cited in June for a zoning violation. But department officials said later that the violation involved a city Art Commission complaint over the sign's lettering.

DOC.HEAD: Proposed Japanese Force Would Include Military Personnel
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan has proposed sending a 1,000-member group that includes defense forces and retired military personnel to the Persian Gulf, a newspaper reported today. Only about 100 of the proposed ``U.N. peace cooperation corps'' would be members of the Self Defense Forces, Japan's military, the newspaper Asahi Shimbun said, citing unidentified government sources. Other members of the proposed group - similar to a reserve unit - would be retired military personnel and volunteers from local police and fire departments, it said. The team would limit itself to technical assistance such as medical service, surveillance, communications, transport and construction, news reports said. The force would allow Japan to contribute to the buildup in the Persian Gulf despite the nation's ban on sending troops overseas. Japan, as the world's second-largest economy, has felt increasing pressure from the United States to move beyond its promise of $4 billion in gulf aid to a more active role. Some leading members of the governing Liberal Democratic Party want to break free of the constitutional ban on using military force to settle international conflicts. The party, however, has been weakened by a series of election setbacks. It is afraid of igniting a fierce battle in Parliament with the leading opposition Socialist Party, which strongly opposes any change in the constitution or in the Self Defense Forces Law. ``We will hve to be very careful how to handle this matter,'' chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto said today. ``We have to make sure to build consensus within the party first.'' In Japan, any prospect of renewed militarism usually arouses fear and bitterness. It is an issue politicians like to avoid, and the current U.N. peace cooperation bill is being laboriously designed to skirt such constitutional questions. The planned corps would report directly to the prime minister. Self Defense Forces personnel serving in the unit probably would assume a special status as civilian government employees. In any case, events in the gulf may bypass the government's political maneuvering. Officials say it's likely to be at least 1{ months before the peace cooperation corps could be formed, even if the bill sails smoothly through Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Militants Kill 40 Fishermen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to CORRECT name of village, UPDATES that military to arm villagers. Pickup 6th graf, `Tamil rebels...'
DOC.TEXT: Tamil gunmen stormed a fishing village on the west coast, killing at least 40 Sinhalese people with machetes and automatic rifles, military officials said today. Wednesday's attack in the Vellamundel village, 110 miles north of Colombo, is the latest in a series of killings of civilians by the Tamil rebels, the Sinhalese-dominated army and Moslem militant groups. The military officials said about 30 Tamil guerrillas raided the village from jungle hideouts in the interior. After the attack, they split into two groups, one heading for the coast and the other toward the jungle, they said. At least 30 huts in the village were set ablaze, the officials said. Word of the attack reached the army when five Sinhalese men, with gunshot and stab wounds, made it to a military camp, the officials said. Defense Secretary, Gen. Cyril Ranatunga later ordered deployment of troops into the area and increased the number of government militiamen. The government also decided to issue firearms and hand grenades to the villagers to protect themselves against ``such barbaric onslaughts,'' a government statement said. Tamil rebels have been fighting for an independent homeland since 1983. Their war against the Sinhalese-dominated government and military resumed in June this year after a 13-month cease-fire. At least 3,000 combatants have been killed in the fighting since June. Many civilians have died, but there are no estimates of the number of deaths. Civilian deaths have been reported in government attacks on rebel-held territory and in raids by the Tamils on villages. The rebels have targetted members of the Sinhalese community and Moslems, whom they accuse of supporting the army. Armed Moslems have been accused of revenge attacks on Tamil civilians. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 millin people and Sinhalese comprise 75 percent. Moslems make up about 7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Lost Arm in Drunken Fall Onto Subway Tracks Wins $9.3 Million
DOC.TEXT: A man who lost an arm after falling on the subway tracks while drunk has been awarded $9.3 million by a jury. ``God bless America,'' said Francisco Marino, a Mexican citizen who had been in the United States for one year working as a dishwasher before the April 1989 accident. City transit officials said they would appeal Wednesday's state Supreme Court decision, which compensates Marino, 30, for pain and suffering and loss of earnings. He was hit by a northbound train after falling. ``We're outraged and we are confident that this will be overturned on appeal,'' said a Transit Authority spokesman Termaine Garden. His lawyer, Alan Shapey, contended Marino would not have fallen in front of the train if transit officials had followed their guidelines to ``take charge'' of disabled or intoxicated people, at least until a police officer arrives, to ensure their safety. Shapey argued that, although a transit clerk reported Marino's presence on the platform, the man was not removed.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf at a Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughoutwith latest detail. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:

Iraq Thursday asked U.S. networks to broadcast a videotaped message by Saddam Hussein to the American people. Iraq's information minister Latif Nassayef Jassim was quoted by the Iraqi News Agency as requesting the U.S. TV time. He did not disclose what Saddam's message says, but it is likely a rebuttal to President Bush's speech to the Iraqi people televised Sunday. --- Organizers of the Asian Games Thursday banned Iraq from the competition, which begins Saturday in Beijing. Delegates leaving a closed meeting of the 38-member council in Beijing said that of those present, 27 voted today to expel Iraq, three opposed expulsion, five abstained and one ballot was invalid. Approval of two-thirds of voting delegates was needed to pass the ban. Abstentions did not count. --- An American soldier was killed and two others injured Thursday in a jeep accident in the Saudi Arabian desert, U.S. military officials said. The death brought to four the number of fatalities among American personnel since Operation Desert Shield began in early August. All were accidental. --- Iraq's information minister was quoted as saying Thursday that Iraq will knock out Persian Gulf oil fields if attacked by multinational forces assembled in Saudi Arabia. --- French soldiers, including Foreign Legionnaires, gathered in the French port of Toulon Thursday to begin a four-day sealift for Saudi Arabia. About 4,000 ground troops will take part in France's largest sealift in at least 30 years. --- A charter flight carrying American women and children from Kuwait was heading to North Carolina Thursday after a stopover in London. The last flight is scheduled to depart on Saturday, the State Department said, leaving behind hundreds of mostly male American hostages. --- Lebanon's civil war-wracked economy got some help from Saudi Arabia. The Lebanese government said Thursday it has received $100 million from the Saudis to help offset the loss of funding promised by Kuwait and oil-rich Arab governments now faced with the gulf crisis. --- British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said the U.N. Security Council's five permanent members - the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France and China - had agreed to extend the trade embargo against Iraq to air traffic. The resolution is expected to be put to a vote in the 15-member council on Friday or Saturday, diplomats said.

DOC.HEAD: Sports Body Ousts Iraqis From Asian Games
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 4 grafs after 2nd, `Delegates leaving...,' to CORRECT Yemen sted Jordan voted for ban, and CORRECT name of Kuwaiti Olympic Committee president, ADDS background on Palestine member. Pickup 6th graf, `The voting...'; Subs 9th graf to CLARIFY Iraq intended to compete but athletes had not yet arrived.
DOC.TEXT: The Olympic Council of Asia voted today to expel Iraq from the Asian Games and from the council as punishment for its invasion of Kuwait, delegates said. Delegates leaving a closed meeting of the 38-member council said that of those present, 27 voted to expel Iraq, three opposed expulsion, five abstained and one of the ballots was invalid. Iraq, Yemen and the Palestine representatives opposed expulsion, said Roy De Silva of Sri Lanka, vice chairman of the meeting. Mongolia and Afghanistan did not vote, but the reason was not immediately known. Palestine is recognized as an associate member by the Olympic Council of Asia and allowed to enter the Games and vote in council meetings. Palestine is not recognized by the International Olympic Committee. The council's president, Sheik Fahad Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah of Kuwait, was killed when Iraqi troops stormed the royal palace following the Aug. 2 invasion. ``We the Kuwaitis have justice on our side,'' said his son, Ahmed Fahd Al-Sabah, president of Kuwait's National Olympic Committee. The voting took less than 30 minutes, and it was not immediately clear why the one ballot was invalidated. Approval of two-thirds of voting delegates was needed to pass theban. Abstentions did not count. Delegates said Iraq was suspended from the council until Kuwait's National Olympic Committee is able to function normally in its homeland. Most of Kuwait's competitors were trapped in the country following the Iraqi invasion. Some Kuwaiti athletes, who were outside their nation when Iraq invaded, have arrived in Beijing to compete. The Games open Saturday and close Oct. 7. At least 31 nations representing about 4,300 athletes have agreed to participate in the games, held every four years. Iraq had declared its intention to compete, but its athletes had not yet checked in at the Games village. ``We feel sorry for the (Iraqi) athletes. We feel more sorry for the spirit of Olympism. This is a victory for everything illegal,'' said Abdul Karim Al-Mulla, president of Iraq's National Olympic Committee. ``It is clear that there was great pressure.'' An Iraqi National Olympic Committee statement described the expulsion as ``a clear and flagrant violation of the OCA constitution and all its principles and values of fair treatment for all members.'' Today's council meeting began with all delegates, including the Iraqis, standing in a moment of silence for the slain council president, delegates said. Ahmed Fahd Al-Sabah said he was ``very overwhelmed'' by the prayer for his father. He said the vote would help the morale of the few Kuwaiti athletes at the Games. ``But, unfortunately, most of our athletes cannot participate,'' he said. ``In any case, they feel now that the whole world and Asia are with them.'' The six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council, which includes Kuwait, initially threatened to boycott the 16-day event if Iraq was allowed to compete. But Kuwait later backed down from the boycott threat, saying it would resort to that only if the council meeting were ``unfair.'' China, eager for the first full-attendance Asiad ever, had been seeking to reconcile the two sides, while many smaller Asian countries have shown reluctance to enter into the fray. In a meeting Saturday in Beijing, the council's 11-member executive bureau recommended Iraq be barred from both the games and membership in the council, but left the final decision to the general assembly.

DOC.HEAD: Church Orders Theater Company to Stop Performing
DOC.TEXT: An avant-garde theater company was ordered to quit performing its play called ``The Cardinal Detoxes'' or face eviction by the landlord: the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. The RAPP Theater Co., part of the RAPP Arts Center, agreed in its lease with the church not to present such works in the building, a former parochial school. But R. Jeffrey Cohen, RAPP's founder and artistic director, called the archdiocese's threat an attempt at censorship and promised to fight it in court. ``We will not buckle under the pressure,'' Cohen said. ``My attorneys have been looking into it and they are convinced that the church's position is unconstitutional as well as being unconscionable.'' The play by Thomas M. Disch, drama critic of The Nation, is a 35-minute monologue about an archbishop who has been placed in a church-run detoxification center because he has killed a pregnant woman in an auto accident while driving drunk. The archbishop delivers a diatribe against church policies on abortion, women's rights, homosexuality and other issues. Cohen said the center received a letter Monday from the archdiocese demanding the theater company ``immediately terminate the performance'' of the play because it violates the center's lease. An archdiocese spokesman, Joseph Zwilling, said the letter did not amount to censorship. The center's lease states that it acknowledges the church owns the land and that any activity offensive to the church's principles ``would be detrimental to the landlord's reputation,'' he said. ``This was agreed to by the tenant after extensive discussions,'' Zwilling said. ``We went over this very carefully. They said they would abide by these principles.'' The RAPP Arts Center is an experimental group that presents avant-garde theater, music, dance and film. Among those it has presented is performance artist Karen Finley, who recently lost a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts after officials said her work would not ``enhance public understanding and appreciation of the arts.'' Cohen said he had not decided if he would defy the church's order and present the play this Friday and Saturday nights.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Tapes Message To The Americans, Says Iraq Could `Hurt America'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Saddam saying in interview that Iraq could fight for six years. Pickup 4th pvs, `Jassim said...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's Saddam Hussein has recorded a message to the American people, and his government has asked that it be broadcast by television networks in the United States, the Iraqi News Agency reported today. Also today, a Turkish newspaper quoted Saddam as saying Iraq could fight for five or six years if war breaks out and ``can hurt America.'' Speaking of the international trade embargo against Iraq, the newspaper Milliyet of Istanbul quoted Saddam as saying in an interview: ``We are preparing ourselves for a blockade that could last for years ... We have fought for eight years (against Iran). If necessary we can fight for another three to four years, another five to six years.'' Saddam was also quoted as saying Iraq ``knows that America is the No. 1 superpower in the world. But we also are confident that we can hurt America.'' Iraq's news agency did not provide any detail of the content of the Saddam's television message for the United States, which is clearly a response to one by President Bush that was broadcast by Iraqi television on Sunday. It quoted Information Minister Latif Nassyif Jassim as saying ``concerned American personalities have been contacted and asked to take delivery of the tape for broadcasting on American television channels.'' Jassim said the Iraqi government still has not received a response to the request ``made on the basis of reciprocal treatment.'' But if the United States blocks the attempt, Jassim said, ``The concerned Iraqi authorities will find alternative ways to transmit the message to the American people through international television stations.'' In his statement, he did not say when the message was taped or give its length. Bush's address to the Iraqis was eight minutes long. It was taped at the White House and delivered with Arabic subtitles and an Arabic-language voiceover. The full text was broadcast on the Iraqi television. U.S. officials have complained about the broadcast time given to Saddam's messages and staged appearances with Western hostages - particularly by the all-news American network CNN. Diplomats say they have helped garner support for Iraq in the Persian Gulf standoff, especially among radical Arab masses. Responding to the complaint, Jassim offered Bush time on the Iraqi television. In Bush's weekend broadcast, he said: ``Iraq stands isolated and alone'' now that the U.N. Security Council has slapped sanctions on it as punishment for its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``Saddam Hussein tells you that the crisis is a struggle between Iraq and America. In fact, it is Iraq against the world,'' he said. The speech sparked widespread anger among Iraqis, who poured into the streets of Baghdad to shout: ``Death to Bush, Death to America!'' Veteran Iraqi announcer Mikdad Morad, who reads many of Saddam's mesages, called Bush's message ``full of lies and contradictions.''

DOC.HEAD: American Soldier Killed, 2 Injured in Jeep Wreck
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd pvs to MOVE UP total number of fatalities. Subs 7th pvs, `Previous fatalities...' to CORRECT ship where sailor electrocuted. Pickup 6th pvs, `The worst...'
DOC.TEXT: An American soldier was killed and two others injured today in a jeep accident in the Saudi Arabian desert, U.S. military officials said. The death brought to 17 the number of fatalities among American personnel since Operation Desert Shield began in early August. All were accidental. Military spokesmen said the latest accident involved a vehicle belonging to the 82nd Airbone Division operating ``off road'' in an undisclosed location. They said the three soldiers were carried by helicopter to Fleet Marine Hospital No. 5 in Saudi Arabia, where one was declared dead on arrival with head injuries. One was undergoing treatment for a dislocated knee and the third was treated and released. Their identities were withheld pending notification of relatives. It was the second accident in two days involving the 82nd Airborne. A soldier was slightly wounded by shrapnel on Wednesday when an artillery round exploded 200 yards from his position during drills. Previous fatalities among U.S. servicemen in the Middle East included a soldier hit by a truck, another killed in a road collision and a sailor electrocuted in a mishap aboard the destroyer USS Antietam in the Persian Gulf. The worst accident involving U.S. servicemen involved in the Persian Gulf standoff occurred on Aug. 29 when a giant C-5A transport aircraft loaded with supplies for U.S. forces in the gulf crashed and burned shortly after takeoff in West Germany, killing 13 crew members.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Official Scolds Allies for Not Doing More for U.S. in Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NATO's top official today criticized the Western allies for not sending more ground forces and other assistance to the Persian Gulf region to support the huge American military buildup. ``Let me clearly state my personal opinion - that some allies could and should do more,'' said Manfred Woerner, secretary-general of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``It would be helpful if, in addition to Great Britain and France, also other allies could send ground troops to the gulf as suggested by the United States,'' he said at a security conference sponsored by the U.S. Mission to NATO. Secretary of State James A. Baker III last week asked the alliance nations to deploy additional ground-based forces in the region - ``even if it were only symbolic.'' Since then, Britain and France have announced they will send thousands of ground troops to the region, but no other NATO nations have joined in. Woerner said the gulf crisis has raised the question of whether NATO should play a greater role in dealing with so-called regional or out-of-area conflicts, which affect the security of member nations. Under NATO's treaty, member nations have agreed to consider an armed attack on any one of them, in Europe or North America, as an attack against all of them. It allows consultations for events occurring outside the area. ``Who could deny that the maintenance of an uninterrupted supply of oil is a vital issue for the security of all the members of the alliance,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish New Year Marked by Police Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with no incidents today. DELETES outdated 8th graf pvs. Picks up 9th graf pvs: ``It was . . .'
DOC.TEXT: Synagogues and a Jewish youth group in this college town known for its liberal politics have been assigned police protection during Rosh Hashana because of an outbreak of anti-Semitic vandalism and harassment. ``Madison has changed; it was so tolerant,'' Jeanne Bleicher said Wednesday night as she left a service for the Jewish New Year, which began at sundown. Police have handled 23 anti-Semitic reports over two months in this home of state government and the University of Wisconsin's main campus. Madison police said no anti-Semitic crimes occurred Wednesday night or during this morning's services. ``Things went just fine. Maybe it's all over,'' said Steven Morrison, director of the Madison Jewish Community Council, adding that the last ``hate crime'' was committed about 10 days ago. Graffiti has appeared on synagogues and the houses of predominantly Jewish fraternities and sororities. Windows have been broken and insults yelled at people on the streets. In July, someone cut the brake lines on a school bus for a Jewish camp. The vandalism was discovered before the bus was used. Police have no suspects, which left the Jewish community jittery as their faith's most solemn holidays approached. Jewish leaders asked police to provide at least one officer for services at the B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundation, an organization for Jewish young people, Temple Beth Israel and Temple Beth El, said Morrison. ``It's sad and outrageous that at this time, in this country and this city, coming down on the side of caution requires having police present,'' Morrison said. ``It was a comfort,'' Irv Saposnik, director of an organization for Jewish students at the university, said of police officers on hand for services. ``Things went wonderfully. The whole city has responded right on target.'' Felicia Roberts, who also attended services, said the Jewish community is just one of many groups targeted for hate crimes. ``There's a small group of people around that aren't tolerant. They never will be,'' she said. ``I don't feel singled out more than any other group.'' The police presence moved Stanleigh Friedman, 76, who attended services at Temple Beth El. ``Hitler's been gone for 45 years, but it seems like he's being awakened,'' he said. Madison has a population of about 170,000. The Jewish population is less than 5 percent. More than 43,000 students are enrolled at the university's Madison campus. Madison was a hotbed of radical anti-Vietnam War sentiment during the 1960s and '70s and is known for its tolerance of ethnic and cultural diversity. Rosh Hashanah, which often is celebrated two days, marks the start of the Jewish faith's 10-day High Holidays that end with Yom Kippur, the day of atonement, on Sept. 29. University student Natalie Antinoff said the anti-Semitic acts motivated her to go to services. ``This is the first time I've come to temple other than for family events in years,'' she said. ``The threats made me want to stand up for my religion by not hiding, by not being afraid but taking a stand and being out in public.''

DOC.HEAD: Socialist Premier Confirmed by Parliament
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Lukanov address on national TV, making land proposal. Pickup 11th graf, `Lukanov's Cabinet...'
DOC.TEXT: Parliament today confirmed Premier Andrei Lukanov, allowing him to continue leading the government despite his failure to form a coalition with opposition parties. The vote followed Lukanov's address on national TV on Wednesday night, when he promised to seek quick passage of new laws to encourage private farming and end decades of state control of the economy. Lukanov appealed for unspecified ``practical measures'' to end state control of most sectors of the economy and replace it with private ownership. He also said tax and banking reforms were needed to stimulate the private sector. He specifically mentioned the need for a land act to boost the development of private farming. Opposition parties are seeking immediate privatization of land and industry, and return of land to those who owned it before it was collectivized under Communist rule. The Socialists, who are former Communists, agree to land reform, but say land should be given to those who are tilling it now. Earlier in the day, the Socialist-dominated Grand National Assembly confirmed Lukanov by a vote of 234-104 with 28 abstentions. Thirty-four deputies were absent. The rest of the Cabinet ministers must be approved by parliament later. It will be Lukanov's second government in seven months. Lukanov repeatedly has urged the opposition to join in a coalition government to forge a program with wide backing in society. But he was forced late Wednesday to propose a new Cabinet dominated by his party, the Socialists, because of continuing opposition reluctance to participate. Leading members of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces have said that the Socialists would not meet their demands for participating in the Cabinet. The Socialists are heirs to the long-ruling Communists, who chose the name change last spring along with departure from an authoritarian past and won a parliamentary majority in June's watershed free elections. The Socialists have since seen their popularity wane, however, because of Bulgaria's faltering economy. Some basic foodstuffs and consumer goods are in short supply or unavailable, and the government began rationing of sugar, cooking oil and other goods during the summer. Electricity is being rationed, and the government this week banned food exports apparently to ensure the country has adequate supplies this winter. Lukanov's Cabinet contained only a handful of new faces, but included the first new defense minister in 28 years. Lukanov replaced Dobri Dzhurov with Yordan Mutafchiev. Dzhurov was a close associate of former Communist Party chief Todor Zhivkov but was credited with helping party reformers remove the hard-line leader in November. Science Minister Ilya Konev is the only Cabinet member not associated with the Socialist Party. Two others, Labor and Social Welfare Minister Emilia Maslarova, and Culture Minister Dimo Dimov, are not formally members of the Socialist Party but were endorsed by the Socialists when they ran for parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Eager for Improved Cuban-American Relations
DOC.TEXT: A senior adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today the Soviet Union is eager to see the United States and Cuba normalize their relations and is prepared to help in the process. Speaking to members of The Associated Press board of directors and Associated Press executives, Presidential Council member Yevgeny Primakov also said the Soviet Union will not base future aid to Cuba solely on the political consideration of keeping President Fidel Castro in power. Questions about Cuba figured prominently in the wide-ranging discusion with Primakov, who also said the Soviet Union has ``stopped thinking of exporting revolution in any form.'' Asked if Cuba has made a similar decision, Primakov said: ``They are now reconsidering a lot of their policies.'' He added that others, presumably meaning the United States, ``should absolutely forget about exporting counterrevolution.'' Primakov said the Soviet Union wants Cuba to be ``a factor of stability'' in international politics and said his country would like to see the normalization of Cuban-American relations. ``We are prepared to help bring this about,'' he said. Asked if the decline of Soviet aid to Cuba could cause the fall of Castro, Primakov said: ``I don't think the Castro government is that unstable.'' He said Cuba does not depend exclusively on aid from the Soviet Union and that trade between the two countries is mutually beneficial. ``I don't think Castro is competely dependent'' on the Soviet Union, Primakov said, adding that the Soviet Union ``won't be completely guided by the political considerations of keeping Castro in power'' as it reviews its aid and trade policies with Cuba.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Tax Increases
Mitchell States Conditions for Approving Capigan Gains Cut
DOC.TEXT: Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell said today a deficit-reduction plan should include a cut in taxes on capital gains. He later explained he was not advocating a reduction, but spelling out conditions under which one might be approved. President Bush's repeated call for a capital-gains cut has been a major obstacle to agreement between the White House and congressional leaders on a deficit-reduction plan. Mitchell's all-out opposition prevented approval of the capital-gains provision last year. Mitchell, D-Maine, was being interviewed today on the C-SPAN network when a telephone caller asked why, since he favored a capital-gains cut in 1986, he now is so opposed. ``I do believe that we should enact it as part of this (deficit-reduction) package now, but in a manner that makes it part of a fair and progressive tax structure and which does not increase the budget deficit,'' Mitchell responded. Meeting with reporters later, Mitchell denied that he now is advocating a capital-gains cut. He said any reduction must meet the three tests: ``It must be part of a fair and progressive system, it should not bust the deficit and it should be targeted to investment and small business.'' Bush and other advocates of a cut in taxes on capital gains, which are profits from the sale of investments, say it is needed to promote investment and create jobs. In the C-SPAN interview, Mitchell noted that almost 80 percent of the direct benefits of such a cut would go to people with incomes above $100,000 a year. He said Democrats are telling Bush that if he is to win a capital-gains reduction, it must be offset by raising taxes in other ways on the well-to-do. ``What we have suggested is that we accept a capital-gains differential but it be offset in some way so we don't have a situation where we ask all Americans to sacrifice to deal with the budget deficit except those with incomes of $200,000 a year or more,'' Mitchell said. Unless the wealthy are required to pay for a capital-gains cut, he said, the deficit would be worsened. ``Should we as the first and most important step in trying to reduce the deficit adopt a measure that will increase the deficit?'' he asked. Republicans have proposed that the capital-gains cut be offset by limiting the itemized deductions of higher-income Americans. Democrats have rejected that approach.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Was Declared Dead Is Alive
DOC.TEXT: A man who was declared dead and whose estate has been distributed is alive. A notation in the Montgomery County Circuit Court file reads, ``After sworn testimony, Judge (William C.) Miller formally noted that Dennis Rarick is not deceased.'' Rarick, now 49 and living in San Marcos, Calif., said he was deeply depressed when he disappeared in 1976 for ``personal reasons.'' `I left the Montgomery County area and assumed a new identity because I was emotionally unable to cope with certain circumstances of my personal life at that time,'' he said. ``I had a choice of commiting suicide or going away and getting myself together,'' Rarick told The Washington Times in a telephone interview. He moved to British Columbia, assumed the name of Leonard Allen Cohn, and then came back to the United States. He received a doctorate in computer science from Columbia University, got married and eventually settled in California. ``Instead of saying I found happiness, it's better to say I found less stress,'' Rarick told the newspaper. Last December, Cohn told his wife he was really Rarick. The revelation led to counseling, but Rarick said, their relationship is stronger than ever. Meanwhile, his estate grew. In 1986, Rarick's father, a retired mechanical engineer in Indiana, began distribution of his son's estate, which had grown to about $81,000. Rarick told Miller on Sept. 12 he made no claim on the estate. `If I wanted that, I shouldn't have disappeared in the first place,'' he told the Times Wednesday. He did, however, receive a refund of about $7,700 from the Internal Revenue Service in inheritance taxes. ``Nobody suffered material loss,'' Rarick said. ``A lot of people suffered emotional harm, my own family particularly.'' He has taken steps to change his name back. His two teen-aged sons have already changed their names to Rarick. Rarick talked to his father in December and learned that his mother died four years ago. He said his family has been `very accepting and open and loving. My friends are having a much more difficult time coping.''

DOC.HEAD: Courthouse Bombing May Be Work Of White Supremacist Group
DOC.TEXT: A white supremacist organization asked that hate-crime laws be repealed and hinted that its members were responsible for a bombing which damaged the federal courthouse. In a letter received Tuesday by KNSD-TV, a group called The Holy Church of the White Fighting Machine of the Cross said it is seeking the nullification of ``all anti-white laws pertaining to hate crimes.'' It also asks ``that new trials be given to incarcerees due to hate crimes.'' The previously unknown group did not specifically claim responsibility for last weekend's bombing, which blew out two glass courthouse doors. Its letter said that, while no one was hurt, the group ``cannot guarantee there will not be injuries in the future.'' Station officials turned the letter over to the FBI, which is investigating the bombing. ``Obviously the existence of a letter does not prove anybody did the bombing,'' said FBI agent Gene Riehl. ``It's just part of the investigation process.'' In the latest instance of apparent hate crimes in the San Francisco Bay area, students and staff at two schools in Haywood said they were angered by bigoted symbols and slogans that were painted on the schools. ``We're outraged. It's something we won't tolerate in Hayward or our high school,'' said Larry Ratto, principal at Hayward High School, which was painted with swastikas and racial epithets Tuesday. Similar derogatory slogans and the letters KKK were painted on the King Intermediate School on Sunday. Police had no suspects. In San Diego, authorities said four men described as ``military-looking'' were seen running from the area of the downtown San Diego courthouse shortly before a homemade bomb detnated about 12:45 a.m. Saturday. The one-page, typewritten letter also says the U.S.-Mexico border should be closed by the National Guard to prevent illegal immigration. ``A time frame of 30 days will be granted by WHITE POWER to effect this, before further action,'' the letter said. Roberto Martinez, a high-profile immigrant rights activist in San Diego, also received a hate letter recently from The Holy Church of the White Fighting Machine of the Cross. Martinez also is director of the U.S.-Mexico Border Program in the San Diego area for the American Friends Service Committee. The 73-year-old Quaker organization carries out programs for peace and justice in 30 countries. The letter to Martinez is filled with expletives and racial slurs, and warns him to ``stop criticizing the Border Patrol.'' That letter was one of several that Martinez said he has received, along with threatening phone calls from more than one white supremacist group. The letter to Martinez is being investigated as a hate crime, police said.

DOC.HEAD: School District Told Cars a Key Ingredient in Teaching Students to Drive
DOC.TEXT: The key to a successful driver education course is the key to a car, say parents and students who have started a drive to have local schools keep using automobiles as teaching tools. A $246.7 million budget adopted Tuesday by the Leon County School Board includes only $10,000 for driver education. School officials say $50,000 is needed to buy the 14 cars the program would need. One parent, Marie Kokol, is trying to get auto dealers to donate cars. Student Kevin Kahn has already donated his family's 1976 Plymouth Valiant to the cause. ``It doesn't look too good, but it runs good and has a new battery,'' the 14-year-old said as he handed the keys to school officials at Tuesday's board meeting. The crowd of about 75 people applauded. With money short, Leon County could be forced to teach its students to drive in the classroom instead of the car. That's already the case in two other Florida districts, in Palm Beach and Lake counties. In Palm Beach, classroom instruction is augmented by simulator training, similar to the kind the Army uses to teach soldiers to drive tanks, said Manny Harageones, a driver's education consultant with the state Education Department. ``It's a proven way to teach,'' Harageones said. But John Walker, who supervises driver training for the district, said he hopes to get students back into cars as soon as possible. Lake County Superintendent Beverly Haskins says she's just as happy without the hassle of cars and few parents have complained. Students and parents at Tuesday's meeting in Leon County were complaining. ``Until we get behind the wheel, there's nothing really that he can teach us,'' 15-year-old Jeannie Walker said of her driver education teacher at Lincoln High School.

DOC.HEAD: Soweto Mass Funeral Draws Thousands
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said today the African National Congress would resist demands to give its supporters guns even though it understood their desire to defend themselves. Speaking to a mass funeral for 12 people killed in black factional fighting, Mandela called the desire for weapons ``reasonable.'' He said it would be difficult to resist the demand, but the ANC would not hand out guns to untrained people. ANC supporters have been demanding weapons because of the savage street fighting in black townships around Johannesburg that has claimed some 800 lives in the past month. The more than 20,000 people at Jabulani Stadium in Soweto cheered when Mandela, the ANC deputy president, made a surprise appearance. He and other top ANC officials had been meeting since Tuesday to discuss the violence and government responses to end it. Mandela criticized recent government security measures to stop the unrest, saying they were intended to arm the white government and disarm ``liberation movements.'' His wife, Winnie Mandela, arrived earlier and stood with the ANC leaders on the stage. The crowd sang revolutionary songs and chanted anti-apartheid slogans. Police said today that 478 bodies from the weeks of fighting remained unclaimed in state mortuaries and would be disposed of soon in pauper funerals. The Soweto police spokesman, Capt. Mikhachane Ngobeni, told the independent South African Press Association that one mortuary contained 270 unclaimed bodies, most of them unidentified. The violence has eased in recent days. Police strung razor wire around the Merafe hostel in Soweto as part of measures to try to halt the fighting. Several dozen armed policemen patrolled outside the hostel. President F.W. de Klerk met Wednesday with his Cabinet and later announced new steps designed to curb the unrest, including special investigative teams to probe specific incidents. He also announced an amnesty for any group or individual surrendering illegal firearms and explosives by Oct. 1. De Klerk's steps followed last week's announcement of new police measures, including roadblocks, weapons searches, isolating flash points such as workers' hostels and squatter camps, and sending in more police and soldiers. Mandela has predicted the police measures would be ineffective. He also has said the ANC could suspend peace talks with the white-led government if security forces fail to halt the bloodshed. The fighting has pitted Xhosas and other blacks linked to the ANC against Zulu supporters of the conservative Inkatha movement. It spread from the eastern Natal Province, the traditional Zulu homeland, where five years of clashes have killed more than 5,000 people. SAPA reported that several ANC and Inkatha officials met Wednesday night in Durban, in Natal, to discuss the violence. It was the first meeting between top officials of the two groups since 1979.

The bulk of Iraqi forces in Kuwait appear to be poor, confused teen-agers, but crack Republican Guards are tightening their control over the city, Kuwaitis fleeing their country say. Refugees interviewed over the past few days at this border crossing said Iraqi troops were becoming increasingly violent in their campaign to force Kuwaitis to accept Iraqi occupation. Checkpoints every 900 feet are now controlled by at least one Republican Guard, who makes sure that searches are thorough. Neighborhood searches have also become more intense, with whole areas completely cut off with six or eight roadblocks as up to 20 soldiers comb each house, said the refugees, who generally spoke on condition of anonymity to protect family members left behind from possible retribution. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - George Washington was barely into his second year as president when the government slapped a tax on whiskey. Cigarettes were targeted during the Civil War. Furs and other luxuries were taxed to help finance World War I. Now Congress and the Bush administration are eyeing those products and others in the search for revenues with which to fight a new war - the long-running battle against the budget deficit. Despite lingering disagreement over several deficit-reduction proposals, chiefly President Bush's plan to cut taxes on capital gains, negotiators for Congress and the White House have agreed tentatively on a half-dozen tax increases that would affect million of Americans. The federal government faces $100 billion worth of arbitrary cuts in most programs Oct. 1 - barely a month before elections - unless a deficit reduction plan can be enacted. ---= ALBANY, N.Y. (AP) - Pierre Rinfret, the Republicans' last-minute, bottom-of-the-barrel choice to run against Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo, is out of money, out a campaign manager and practically out of the race. John Denny, Rinfret's deputy campaign manager, said Wednesday there was ``a strong possibility'' Rinfret will stop actively campaigning because of money woes. The millionaire economist, who in recent months had been derided by prominent members of his own party as a ``buffoon'' and ``brainless wonder,'' accused state GOP leaders of failing to back him financially. ``Our financial situation is so desperate that I'm probably going to have to shut down our entire operation this Friday,'' Rinfret, 66, wrote to GOP leaders Tuesday. ``I thought you should know that all of our money is gone.'' Rinfret's dark-horse challenge to Cuomo's bid for a third, four-year term marks the first run for public office for the former unpaid adviser to President Nixon. ---= SPRINGFIELD, Ill. (AP) - Illinois is witnessing a political role reversal this fall in the campaign for governor: a Democrat running as a tax-cutting, budget-slashing fiscal conservative, and a Republican under attack as a tax-and-spend liberal. Republican Jim Edgar has found himself on the defensive against Democrat Neil Hartigan's anti-tax rhetoric, and recent polls have indicated the race is virtually a dead heat. ``Edgar has got to find a way to deal with the tax issue,'' says political scientist Paul Green of Governors State University. ``It could sink him. It's more than a one-shot issue, it's the dominant issue.'' Edgar is a former state lawmaker and aide to four-term Gov. James R. Thompson. The 52-year-old Hartigan was launched into statewide politics in the early 1970s by the late Chicago Mayor Richard J. Daley. ---= MADISON, Wis. (AP) - Synagogues and a Jewish youth group in this college town known for its liberal politics have been assigned police protection during Rosh Hashana because of an outbreak of anti-Semitic vandalism and harassment. ``Madison has changed; it was so tolerant,'' Jeanne Bleicher said Wednesday night as she left a service for the Jewish New Year, which began at sundown. Police have handled 23 anti-Semitic reports over two months in this home of state government and the University of Wisconsin's main campus. Graffiti has appeared on synagogues and the houses of predominantly Jewish fraternities and sororities. Windows have been broken and insults yelled at people on the streets. In July, someone cut the brake lines on a school bus for a Jewish camp. The vandalism was discovered before the bus was used.
