DOC.HEAD: Latest of the Hard-bodies Joins the Action Market
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Death Warrant'' opened Sept. 14.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Jean-Claude Van Damme, the latest of the hard-bodies to join the action movie market, likes to say that he came to Hollywood with my legs, just as Arnold Schwarzenegger came with his muscles. Van Damme claims that the comparison to top pectoral-man Schwarzenegger is minimal: ``All the newspapers compare me to Arnold. But we are very different. I came from Belgium, he came from Austria. They have tendency in the business always to compare people.'' Not without reason. Both men have a fanatical devotion to their bodies. Both are as shrewd as Wall Street lawyers about their careers. And both have a charming faculty for mangling the English language. But unlike Schwarzenegger, Van Damme would like future films to take a romantic turn. ``I get lots of fan mails from ladies,'' the Belgian said. ``They say, `We love your movies and love the action, but we would like to see you in the romantic type of film, with some feeling and some passion.' ``That's my next film, `Double Impact.' I'm going to play (a) twin,'' he said. ``I'm going to play a guy like a James Bond, very clean, very charming. ... In real life, I'm very hyper, a very happy person. I'm always laughing. In all those movies I'm very serious. That's not my nature.'' Van Damme's newest movie is MGM-UA's ``Death Warrant'' in which he plays an undercover cop from French Canada (which helps explain the accent). Railroaded into a California prison, he defends himself with the only weapons available: his feet. Born 29 years ago in Brussels, Van Damme began studying martial arts at 11, and became a middleweight champion as a teen-ager. He also grew up loving movies, and he left a thriving gym business to try his luck in Hollywood. He worked as limo driver, carpet layer, bouncer and karate instructor while seeking jobs in movies. ``The problem was when I came in this country I wasn't legal,'' he said. ``When you don't have a green card, you have to do all those jobs to make money. I'm very legal now, but it was very difficult. ``It's good in one sense because you can see what's going on in the bottom. When you start in the bottom with low-budget movies, you have to work with everybody, and you can see what's going on with the crew, you respect all the people. ... It's a big family. It's not just you, it's a big family.'' A villainous role in ``No Retreat, No Surrender'' led to an alien part in Schwarzenegger's ``Predator.'' Then he became a star in ``Cyborg,'' ``Bloodsport'' and ``Kickboxer.'' Naturally, the Van Damme films are popular in Asia, and he's beginning to pick up fans elsewhere. ``I am growing all over, very nicely,'' he said. ``Not too fast, not too slow, just perfect. ... Nobody knew me in the U.S. market before, so they bought the movies in videos. I started to have a relationship with the video people; now they come to see me in theaters. So it's growing very nicely.'' Van Damme realistically views the future: ``The future will decide my destiny. It's what's on the screen that will pay off. It's difficult to say I'm going to do this or that. I'm going to go with life. ``The most important thing is to stay hungry. ... I know it's going to take time. I've got to build a reputation, I've got to connect with the people watching those movies and the press and everything. It's going to take time, but I think - I think - I'll be there.''

DOC.HEAD: For Writer Shelby Foote, Narrative History Is Way To Truth
DOC.TEXT: After devoting 20 years to his three-volume history of the Civil War, Shelby Foote figured he was finished with the era and could get back to work on his seventh novel. Enter documentary filmmaker Ken Burns, who enlisted him as a commentator for ``The Civil War,'' the epic, 11-hour TV series starting Sunday and running five nights on PBS. Suddenly, a national audience has ``discovered'' Shelby Foote. ``This Civil War stuff is driving me crazy. I thought I had my discharge,'' he says in the quiet, upstairs study where he wrote the final volume of his 3,000-page history, ``The Civil War: A Narrative.'' ``People keep wanting me to come somewhere and speak and I enjoy it. But I disapprove of it,'' Foote said. ``I'm doing it, but it really takes me out of my work.'' Foote, 73, writes in longhand with an old-fashioned pen and inkwell, aiming for 600 words a day. ``It makes me take my time and get it right,'' he said. His used his southern storyteller's touch in his history, and his courtly Mississippi drawl is the documentary's unifying voice. He has a scholar's insight and a sympathetic feeling for both sides of the conflict. Foote said he was drawn to the documentary by Burns' insistence on historical accuracy. Words like ``truth'' and ``accuracy'' come up often in a conversation with him. ``Without that,'' he said, ``you've got nothing.'' Narrative history, Foote said, was the only way to write about the Civil War. ``Narrative history is the kind that comes closest to telling the truth,'' he said. ``You can never get to the truth, but that's your goal.'' A three-time Guggenheim fellow and recipient of a Ford Foundation fellowship, Foote finished his sixth novel, ``September, September'' in 1978. Then he went to work on his reading. He did nothing else for three years. ``Whenever I do anything that I consider gives me the right to do it, I sit down and spend a month reading Marcel Proust,'' he said. ``I've read `Remembrance of Things Past' eight times as a reward for various things.'' Foote grew up in Greenville, Miss., and was a lifelong friend of author Walker Percy. A part-time ``jackleg reporter'' for Hodding Carter on The Delta Star, he also edited his high school newspaper and was often at odds with his principal. Rejected by the University of North Carolina in 1935, he learned that the principal was behind it but went to enroll anyway. ``When I got to the desk, they said, `We told you not to come.' I said, `I know you did, but I didn't think you really meant it.' '' He stayed two years, taking whatever courses he wanted, regardless of their value for a degree. After college, he took make-do jobs and worked on his first novel. With war on the horizon, he joined the National Guard in 1939. Foote was a field artillery captain training in northern Ireland when a superior officer ``insulted one of my men on an inspection. I made him apologize to the man,'' he said. Not long after, he was court-martialed for ``falsifying a government record'' - his mileage on a jaunt in military vehicle. It cost him his commission. He was discharged and returned to the United States. Foote worked in the New York bureau of The Associated Press, but journalism didn't appeal to him. He joined the Marine Corps. ``The Marines had a great time with me. They said if you used to be a captain, you might make a pretty good Marine,'' Foote said. The war ended before he made private first class. He went back to Greenville to write commercials for a radio station. ``Then I sold my first story to the Saturday Evening Post. I quit my job and haven't had another one since,'' he said. Foote's first novel ``Tournament,'' begun before the war, was published in 1949. Then came ``Follow Me Down'' in 1950, ``Love in a Dry Season'' in 1951, ``Shiloh'' in 1952 and ``Jordan County'' in 1954. That year, Random House asked him to write a one-volume history of the Civil War. He took the job but soon realized it would produce nothing new. He proposed a three-volume history. ``They had various meetings, I suppose,'' he said, ``and in a week or 10 days, they wrote back and said `Go ahead.' I went ahead for the next 20 years.'' --- Elsewhere in televison ... TIME SHIFTER ALERT!!!: Set your VCRs for ``Against the Law,'' premiering Sunday night. It's far and away the best show on Fox's new schedule and the best courtroom drama since ``L.A. Law.'' Michael O'Keefe's bravura creation of maddog Boston trial lawyer Simon MacHeath is the best performance of the fall season. The incredibly talented supporting cast includes Fritz Weaver as a soulless Brahmin lawyer. The two-hour premiere is a detailed, knowing portrait of Boston and Boston lawyers. It's not to be missed.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Are Obsessed With Food
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphics, Logo
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Americans were not always so thin-obsessed; a belly once was a sign of prosperity. As the middle classes began to prosper, however, their figures did, too, and plump became decidedly ordinary. The yearning for a thin body has developed into far more than a temporary fancy. ---

In childhood, chef David Liederman recalls his brother and his stepfather lunging - forks first - toward the last pork chop. Dad speared the brother, and in the chaos, Liederman came up with the chop. ``We were so eager to get to the portion that we barely tasted what we were eating and whatever hit the table was devoured as if hit by a buzz saw,'' he said. Liederman was off on a decades-long journey of devouring that eventually led him to map trips through France aimed at hitting as many three-star restaurants as possible. At 38, he topped 300 pounds. He opened two New York City restaurants and a chain of chocolate chip cookie shops, called David's Cookies. And though he has dropped 100 pounds, kept it off for three years and writen a book, ``David's Delicious Weight-Loss Program,'' he remains obsessed with food. ``My biggest project in life is keeping from getting fat,'' said Liederman, now 41. ``If you believe the way I do that compulsive eating is not only a sickness but an addiction, how do you get rid of the problem without spending the psychological energy?'' One therapist likened his situation to ``psychological tyranny.'' But Liederman, for now, is content. He carries a pocket diary everywhere, recording every single taste of food in tiny little letters, down to the spoonful of clear broth and mushroom soup tasted at his Broadway Cafe. He is fanatic about daily exercise, usually with a trainer. At 5-foot-11 and about 180 pounds, he looks healthy and moves fast. ``My goal in life is for someone to say, `You look terrible, David. Eat something,' '' he said. Millions of Americans feel an immediate affinity with those words. Half the adult women and 30 percent of adult men in this country are on a diet. Americans spent more than $30 billion trying to lose weight or keep it off last year, and a congressional committee is investigating the industry. Still, an estimated 34 million American adults are obese - that is, they weigh at least 20 percent above their ideal weight. ``The aesthetic ideal is so lean, and now athletic, that it's simply impossible for many people to attain that ideal,'' said Kelly Brownell, co-director of the Obesity Research Clinic at the University of Pennsylvania. ``Many people lose to a healthy weight, but they don't feel satisfied. ``They push beyond to the aesthetic ideal, and their body fights back, their body wins, and they end up at a higher weight.'' Americans turn to self-help books, relaxation techniques, Overeaters Anonymous, Weight Watchers, modified fasts, liquid diets, liposuction, wired jaws, stapled stomachs, grapefruits, acupuncture, hypnotism, fatty photos on the refrigerator, fake fats, artificial sugars, jogging, spas, aerobics, Stairmasters, gyms, drugs. Dieting is part of the mainstream; going off a diet is failing. That philosophy is part of the problem, according to therapists who say food represents other problems. If people learned to eat to ease hunger for food, rather than hunger for love or something else, most eventually would reach a weight that's good for them, they say. Financially, emotionally and physically, Americans are paying for being so persistently and obsessively focused on an ideal they most likely will never attain. Why? For one thing, women, and men to a lesser extent, are victims of a culture that worships a sylphlike figure to the virtual exclusion of other body types. ``You can't work with women and not work with eating problems, body image,'' said Andrea Gitter, a therapist at the Women's Therapy Center Institute in New York City who specializes in eating problems. ``It touches on everybody's insecurity. The underlying message is that you're not OK as you are,'' said Gitter, who was a compulsive eater until she learned to eat to satisfy physical hunger rather than to stave off guilt, loneliness or other emotional longings. Women often believe that if they are thin, if they control their appetites, they will be happy, loved and respected, Kim Chernin writes in ``The Obsession.'' Losing weight, Hillel Schwartz argues in his book ``Never Satisfied,'' has become ``the modern expression of an industrial society confused by its own desires and therefore never satisfied.'' The obsession strikes girls early. A 1986 study in San Francisco found that of 500 girls in grades 4 to 12, almost 80 percent of 10-and 11-year-olds reported dieting to lose weight. And many parents have overreacted to researchers' warnings that television-addicted children would grow obese; nutritionists had to admonish parents not to take all the fat out of their children's diets. That provides a glimpse at one of the strange aspects of America's obsession with weight: One need not be overweight to live a lifetime dieting. Few people feel content with their bodies. A sort of daily tally sheet is set up: An hour pedaling the exercise bike equals a dish of Haagen Dazs. No breakfast makes fries OK at lunch. A husky guy buys a bag of chips, stuffs a few handfuls in his mouth and tosses the bag in a sidewalk trash bin before he eats too many. Every ounce Oprah Winfrey or Liz Taylor gain and lose is watched by an America gleeful that the famous are no better than we are at keeping thin. Most people believe thin people get paid better, get more dates, live longer, have fewer diseases. But Chernin notes this sense of well-being is precarious, since most of those who lose weight put it all back and more. The solution remains as elusive as the diet that lets you eat what you want and lose weight. ``The history of the diet industry in America probably represents one of the most astounding triumphs of 20th-century capitalist enterprise,'' Joan Jacobs Brumberg writes in ``Fasting Girls.'' ``There is nothing that isn't sold without a thin female body next to it,'' says Susan Gutwill, also with the Women's Therapy Center Institute. ``It's really immoral. It's criminal in a very serious way.'' The $32 billion spent to get thin last year is $10 billion more than was spent just four years ago. And Marketdata Enterprises, a research firm in Valley Stream, N.Y., predicts the market will top $50 billion by 1995. Research may provide more clues to the causes of obesity, but one fact doesn't change: To lose weight and keep it off, you must develop healthy eating and exercise habits for good, the experts say. Even then, you may have to accept a body chunkier than a model's.

DOC.TEXT: Yo-yo dieting - repeatedly losing and regaining weight - may be more dangerous to the cardiovascular system than remaining somewhat overweight, and may even promote weight gain, researchers say. Long-term dieters also need to become educated about nutrition. For example, while the typical American diet includes about 40 percent of its calories from fat, many experts recommend 20 percent to 30 percent. ``They really have very little idea what a portion size means in terms of cutting it,'' Xavier Pi-Sunyer, director of the Obesity Research Center at St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital in New York, said in a recent speech. ``They have very little idea of how much fat is in a food they eat or how much sugar there is in a food they eat.'' Liederman knows his nutrition, exercises daily and appears to have motivation in abundance. But will he keep his weight off? ``I could regress. I could find some rationale I can't foresee,'' Liederman said. ``I could still fall off the wagon.'' Frightening, to a dieter. By World War I, when this country had its first best-selling diet book, there also was a U.S. Food Administration. Herbert Hoover, as its head, called on the nation to eat less. ``Fatness was careless, selfish, wasteful, treacherous and un-American,'' Schwartz wrote. ``There was to the culture of slimming between 1930 and 1960 an element of fear that the more one had, the emptier one would be.'' In 1952, the director of the National Institutes of Health declared obesity the primary national health problem. In 1960, a fitness enthusiast called Jack LaLanne had the largest national daytime television show audience. And before the decade was out, a skinny model called Twiggy became an idol. Obesity today is considered a major health problem, associated with heart disease, diabetes, high blood pressure, joint problems and other diseases. Much, however, remains unknown. ``We don't yet understand how most heavy people get to be heavy,'' Brownell said. Genetics, metabolism, culture, psychology and other things all play a role, but their relative importance is not fully understood, although some people are heavy simply because they eat too much and exercise too little. Many fat people, however, eat no more than thin people. Their bodies seem to use calories less efficiently. Maintaining weight loss seems harder than losing it. Estimates of the recidivism rate commonly top 90 percent, though Brownell suspects that is too high, especially for hospital-based comprehensive programs. These are odds to attract only the foolhardiest bettor, but in dieters hope springs eternal. David Liederman faces his obsession his way, every day. There's his theater district restaurant, the Broadway Cafe; his East Side French restaurant, Chez Louis; and David's Cookies, little takeout shops where the huge chunks of chocolate ooze out of the dough. ``When I was over 300 pounds, I convinced myself I had to taste each batch of cookies - this one might be different than that one,'' Liederman said. Until his doctor told him he might not live to see his daughters grow up. Neither of his young daughters is overweight, but he is vigilant. ``It scares me because I know what it did to me,'' he said. ``If I didn't have this problem, I'd be a lot more productive.''

DOC.TEXT: A congressional subcommittee resumes its investigation into the diet industry, which critics say government has given too much freedom. In the 1970s, at least 58 deaths were blamed on very low-calorie liquid diet programs. Today's programs are safer, though complications still are possible, according to a recent study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association. ``They have always focused on losing weight fast, but the medical community is overwhelming in the view that for the majority of people, losing weight fast can do them more harm than good,'' said U.S. Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., chairman of a House subcommittee on regulation, business opportunities and energy. The subcommittee held two hearings in the spring on health risks, false advertising and profiteering in the diet industry. ``If people look beyond the `Promised Land' approach, plus we can get the (federal regulatory) agencies to do their job, we're on the way to a more sensible approach,'' Wyden, who at 6-foot-4 and 165 pounds never has dieted to lose weight, said in a telephone interview. At Monday's hearing, the subcommittee will consider enforcement efforts aimed at diet promotions and marketing; dieting among adolescents and whether restrictions or warnings are needed for laxatives and other products used to lose weight; and chemical additives in diet products. In a subcommittee staff memo to Wyden, the lack of federal funds for research into obesity is noted. ``Cumulatively, basic diet research at the federal level totals about $12 million per year, and research directed specifically at obestity treatment consumes another $2 million annually.'' This, the memo notes, is from an overall National Institutes of Health research budget of $6.5 billion. About adolescents, the memo says that while diets are not targeted toward teen-agers, young people misuse ``readily available and uncontrolled diet products as a means of furthering dangerous diet practices.'' ``In the face of the significant public health problem presented by obesity, federal policy remains fragmented and undeveloped, diulted and dwarfed in comparision to the research effort on less widespread health concerns,'' according to the memo.

The federally financed study focused on six men who spent 24 hours a day for 13 days in a laboratory, where researchers could precisely measure what they ate. The men did not know the purpose of the study, and they were kept busy with a variety of tasks. Each man ate a high-fat, 844-calorie lunch during one three-day period, and a low-fat, 431-calorie lunch in another period. Both lunches consisted of submarine sandwiches and salad. The men could not distinguish between the two versions. Beginning one hour after lunch, the men could choose from a variety of foods to eat. Analysis showed that if they had eaten the low-calorie lunch, they later made up the difference in calories, mostly at dinnertime. But no such compensation occurred for fat, Rolls said. That suggests fat substitutes ``certainly are going to be an aid to help people to try to reduce fats in foods,'' she said. Hopkins researcher Richard Foltin, lead author of the study, cautioned that the men were not free to eat whatever they wanted for lunch. So the evidence is only suggestive that in everyday life, low-fat food would reduce total fat intake, he said. Adam Drewnowski, director of the human nutrition program at the University of Michigan's School of Public Health, called the study valuable. He also said nobody knows what happens to overall fat intake when people know they are eating low-fat products. Rolls said she doubts those people make up for missing fat. ``I don't think people think in terms of `I want to eat fat,' '' she said. Although the study found no difference in calorie intake, the reduction in calories from fat may still be good news for those trying to lose weight. Recent research suggests calories from fat are more fattening than those from carbohydrates. That is because the body uses less energy to convert fat calories to body fat than it uses to convert carbohydrate calories, Rolls said. In theory, then, cutting back on fat may help in losing weight beyond just the effect on reducing calorie intake, she said. Fat substitutes hit the headlines in February when the Food and Drug Administration approved a substitute called Simplesse for use in frozen desserts. Simplesse is made by Nutrasweet Co. Kraft General Foods Inc. is also seeking FDA approval for a fat substitute to be used in frozen desserts. Another proposed substitute, olestra, could be used in cooking. Olestra is not absorbed by the body, so it would not contribute any fat or calories, says its developer, Procter & Gamble Co. The company proposes that olestra replace some fat in oil and shortening used in the home and in commercial frying. Frito-Lay Inc. is studying an experimental fat substitute, dialkyl dihexadecymalonate, which it says cuts fat by 60 percent when blended with oil for frying tortilla and potato chips.

DOC.HEAD: Anorexia, Bulimia Are Growing Problem for Men
With BC-EXP--Food Obsessed, b0954-b0955
DOC.TEXT: Despite a new focus on being healthy rather than merely thin, anorexia and bulimia continue to haunt young women, and the number of men who suffer from eating disorders appears to be growing. The last decade was full of images of the dangers of eating disorders, on television and in movies and women's magazines. An anorexic teen-ager was a character in the movie ``Down and Out in Beverly Hills.'' Jane Fonda told the world she had suffered from bulimia. Karen Carpenter lost her life to an eating disorder. Even a ``Saturday Night Live'' skit included an anorexic cookbook. The diseases have not gone away, though experts say estimates at the time that 30 percent of college women suffered from them were exaggerated. And new pressures have come to bear on those who are susceptible. ``It's not good enough just to be thin, but one has to have muscles in the right places, for a man or a woman. You get into the fat content of your body, how much muscle tone,'' said Leonard S. Levitz, clincal director of the Renfrew Center in Philadelphia, which in 1985 became the first residential facility for treatment of eating disorders. So now there is ``exercise bulimia,'' in which sufferers turn to extraordinary amounts of exercise rather than, or in addition to, laxatives or vomiting. Anorexia is estimated to be two to four times as common today as 30 years ago. Bulimia also appears to be more common. The best estimates seem to be that 1 percent to 3 percent of college women are afflicted, Levitz said. Anorexia nervosa is characterized by self-starvation, an intense fear of becoming fat and a feeling that one is fat, despite being emaciated. Bulimia involves a pattern of binge eating followed by purging by vomiting or with diruetics. Although anorexia was identified in 1873 by a London physician, there is a centuries-long history of women controlling their appetites, Joan Jacobs Brumberg wrote in her book ``Fasting Girls.'' In the 1300s, St. Catherine of Siena was said to eat only a handful of herbs a day. In the midieval period, fasting was central to female holiness. Bulimia, however, is newer, becoming epidemic only in 1973 or 1974, when ``a lot of trends came together in terms of broad societal issues, concern over body weight, role of women, people being under tremendous pressure to be perfect, the breakdown of family life,'' Levitz said. A victim ``feels powerless in the world, no sense of control of her life, and a real fear that if her eating, like her emotions, got out of control, who knows what would happen,'' Levitz said. Treatment generally is an intensive combination of therapy, education and behavior modification. These generally are diseases of intelligent women, found in the middle and upper classes of developed countries. The incidence appears to be increasing in Scandinavia, Japan and Germany. New research is showing that many of those who suffer from eating disorders dieted as preteen-agers, were sexually abused, or abuse drugs or alcohol, Levitz said. Also linked to the disease are such issues as fear of growth into womanhood. At adolescence, girls come to think of the normal changes occurring in their bodies as fatness and enter a war of wills to control them. Boys, however, take pride in their growth. The overwhelming majority of people with eating disorders are women, but experts say more and more men are afflicted, particularly those involved in weight-conscious pursuits like wrestling, dancing or modeling. Is there a way out? Said Levitz: ``Yes, I think there's a way. And I used to be more hopeful about it happening. The main thing we have to do is change people's perceptions of how you deal with different body weights. How you look is a part of how you are as a person. And there are many, many other things that are equally or more important.''

DOC.HEAD: Fat People Work To End Discrimination
DOC.BYLINE: With BC-EXP--Food Obsessed, b0954-b0955 ^By MARY MacVEAN
DOC.TEXT: At 300 pounds, Helen weighs a little more than she'd like. But at 280, she feels OK. She just thinks it's too bad everyone doesn't see her the way she sees herself. ``I was raised to judge myself, my own success,'' said Helen, who spoke on condition her full name not be used. ``It's how do I feel, and I feel good about myself.'' Helen, 49, credits a positive atmosphere during her childhood. People tell her she looks 35, and she jokes that if she loses weight ``all the wrinkles will show up.'' Helen wears sexy bathing suits, dances, has no trouble attracting men and is becoming something of an activist by speaking out as a member of the non-profit National Association for the Advancement of Fat Acceptance. Founded in 1969, NAAFA has about 3,000 members in this country and Canada. Its aim is to spread the word that everyone, no matter their weight, has a right to a life of dignity and happiness. It does not advocate dieting and tries to debunk ``myths such as that you can lose 10 pounds on a weekend,'' said Barbara Altman Bruno, a clinical social worker in suburban Pleasantville who treats women with weight problems. ``People are meant to be all different shapes and sizes, like vegetables,'' Bruno said. ``I don't think everyone is meant to be thin.'' Helen said she encounters too many people who don't believe that. ``People are taught or conditioned to get their image from the outside world,'' she said. ``I learned over the years, at least in relationships with men, because I have self-confidence and I like myself, whether I'm fat or thin, I attract all sorts of men,'' she said. ``I happen to be a very pretty woman, but I would say I feel a little more protected when I'm a heavy woman. I sort of attract nicer men,'' men who are not only interested in appearances, Helen said. Helen has successfully separated her self-worth from her weight, said Bruno, who sets that goal for the people she treats. ``We are so blinded by fear and hatred of fat in this country,'' she said. America, NAAFA believes, considers discrimination against fat people a ``safe'' prejudice that manifests itself in fashion, availability of insurance, mistreatment by health professionals and nasty jokes. ``In the face of their obesity, our normal standards of humanity vanish and we are possessed by a form of racist revulsion for the bodies of these women,'' Kim Chernin writes in ``The Obsession,'' a philosophical look at the ways women view thin and fat. ``Women are still more valued for how they look than what they do, even though that's been starting to shift'' as women become more prominent professionally and are less reliant on a man for an identity, Bruno said. Most women think they're too fat, because the ideal is impossible for most of them. ``Advertising tells us that to be acceptable as women, we're supposed to be size six and 22 years old,'' Bruno said. Helen and Bruno said they see some positive changes. ``Some people are starting to get smart about the ineffectiveness of diets and liquid diets,'' Bruno said. ``With the national emphasis on cutting back o fat and cholesterol, a little of that is being absorbed by some people.'' More stores carry fashionable clothing for large women, and doctors and employers are changing their attitudes toward heavy people, Helen said. Still, most experts believe obesity is unhealthy, contributing to illnesses including heart disease. And heavy people face other problems. In Glen Burnie, Md., in August, a 367-pound woman was required to take a driving test because authorities thought she might be too fat to drive safely. Regina Guy passed the test, but was angry. ``Fat people are human. We deserve equal treatment,'' said Guy, 25, who was supported by several NAAFA members. ``Because of my size, I should not be discriminated against.'' Her lawyer, Christopher Brown, said it was a clear case of discrimination. ``The only reason she was singled out was because of her weight,'' he said. NAAFA also tries to break a common cycle: Faced with their own distress and the disdain of those around them, overweight people diet, lose weight, go off the diet and get fat. Over and over. Many experts warn against such ``yo-yo'' dieting as dangerous as well as counter-productive: When regaining weight, people often end up fatter than ever. Kelly Brownell, in research at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, found rats took more than twice as long to lose weight the second time around. The difference may be a decrease in metabolic rate, as the body tries to preserve itself against what it perceives as starvation. ``As far as I'm concerned, diets contribute greatly to compulsive overeating and to people getting fatter,'' Bruno said. The yo-yo syndrome brought tragedy to Helen's life, she believes. She and a boyfriend once lost weight together. In months, he lost 75 pounds and regained 60. Soon, he had fatal heart attack. In the depression that followed, Helen regained her weight, too. But Bruno noted that fat people have a lower suicide rate than thin people. ``For some people, food is a way to assuage a lot of painful feelings. It works, it's legal, and relatively inexpensive,'' she said. ``Food happens to be very useful in its place. And delicious.''

DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan told Congress that the Persian Gulf crisis has piled ``new and substantial risks'' on an already faltering national economy. In a generally gloomy assessment of U.S. economic prospects, Greenspan said Wednesday that the jump in oil prices since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait had increased the threat of both higher inflation and a recession. Greenspan did not signal that the Fed either had eased credit already or was planning any immediate easing moves. Instead, he merely repeated comments made in the past that financial markets would respond favorably to a credible deficit reduction package by pushing long-term rates, such as mortgage rates, lower and the Fed would do its part by helping to lower short-term rates. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Housing starts fell 1.7 percent in August to the lowest level since the last recession eight years ago. ``Although we're not technically at a recessionary level, I would describe the industry as in a recession,'' Martin Regalia, an economist with the National Association of Savings Institutions, said after the government released its report Wednesday. ``Recession is a very technical term that gives very little solace to an individual who has to live and breathe in a particular market.'' --- HIGHLAND PARK, Mich. (AP) - Chrysler Corp. dropped some of the bluntest hints yet that it won't accept a model contract that the autoworkers union negotiated with larger rival General Motors Corp. Bennett Bidwell, chairman of the Chrysler Motors subsidiary, suggested Wednesday that Chrysler couldn't afford the health-care provisions of the contract. Robert Lutz, the subsidiary's president, said the income-protection clauses of the GM contract looked costly. --- ST. LOUIS (AP) - Recent reports of big arms sales to countries in the Middle East may be exactly what's needed for U.S. weapons contractors looking to offset cuts in domestic defense spending, analysts say. Possible purchases of American jet fighters, tanks, missiles and other equipment by Saudi Arabia, Israel and even the tiny United Arab Emirates, has lifted some clouds hovering over the defense industry. ``There are still a lot of unknowns, but our future looks a lot brighter than it did six months ago,'' said Don Gilleland, a spokesman for General Dynamics Corp.'s tank-building division in Sterling Heights, Mich. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Troubled Pan Am Corp. will cut 2,500 jobs and some routes, while replacing five large airplanes on trans-Atlantic flights with smaller planes in a bid to emerge as a leaner, stronger airline. Pan Am hopes to save tens of millions of dollars, but the corporate parent of Pan American World Airways refused to provide a more precise estimate after meeting Wednesday with airline analysts. Pan Am Chairman Thomas G. Plaskett said Pan Am will attempt to shift more business into Miami and Latin America, its most lucrative route areas. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - A final decision in the government's conflict-of-interest case against Neil Bush won't be made until next spring, a federal regulator said. The president's 35-year-old son faces a public hearing starting Tuesday in Denver on the government's charges against him. Bush was a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, a Denver thrift that collapsed in late 1988 at a cost to taxpayers estimated at $1 billion. The Office of Thrift Supervision is seeking an order against Bush that effectively could bar him from working for a bank or savings and loan. Bush denies any wrongdoing. --- ATLANTA (AP) - The economy may be sliding into a recession and Atlanta's mid-1980s boom may be over, but economists say the 1996 Olympic Games will give the area an economic shot in the arm that could last into the 21st century. ``Atlanta will be a pocket of prosperity in a dismal national scene,'' said Jeffrey Rosensweig, an assistant professor of finance at Emory University Business School. The Olympics will have a $3.5 billion financial impact on metro Atlanta, including $1.2 billion in direct spending by the Atlanta Organizing Committee, said University of Georgia economist Jeffrey M. Humphreys. --- MUSTANG, Nev. (AP) - The Mustang Ranch, Nevada's oldest and most infamous legal brothel, shut down after filing for bankruptcy liquidation. A trustee says the U.S. government will try to operate the business until it can be sold. A lawyer for owner Joe Conforte said Wednesday that Internal Revenue Service harassment killed a $5 million deal to sell the bordello - more than 100 bedrooms on a 440-acre ranch - and forced it into liquidation in Federal Bankruptcy Court. Officials said Conforte owes $13 million in federal taxes. Conforte has said the debt is no more than $7 million. ---

DOC.TEXT: Recent reports of big arms sales to countries in the Middle East may be exactly what's needed for U.S. weapons contractors looking to offset cuts in domestic defense spending, analysts say. Possible purchases of American jet fighters, tanks, missiles and other equipment by Saudi Arabia, Israel and even the tiny United Arab Emirates, has lifted some clouds hovering over the defense industry. ``There are still a lot of unknowns, but our future looks a lot brighter than it did six months ago,'' said Don Gilleland, a spokesman for General Dynamics Corp.'s tank-building division in Sterling Heights, Mich. News accounts suggest the Saudis want between $18 billion and $23 billion worth of weapons in response to the threat from neighboring Iraq. Israel has requested faster delivery of and additional planes and helicopters. Gilleland said he's heard speculation that the United Arab Emirates is interested in buying 250 tanks. ``About $20 billion would be a nice shot in the arm for the defense industry. I understand it would be pretty far-reaching too,'' said Lawrence Harris, a stock analyst for Bateman Eichler Hill Richards Inc., a Los Angeles-based investment firm. ``But the long-term future of the defense industry is going to remain a function of U.S. defense spending industry and not that of foreign countries,'' Harris said. Foreign sales won't prevent scheduled layoffs by the major contractors, but they may buy time for the industry to adjust to changes at the Pentagon. Analysts said the Persian Gulf military buildup may help prevent deep cuts in he defense budget, currently under discussion in Congress, but won't change the trend toward shrinking the amount of money Americans pay for the military. Offsetting that continuing decline with foreign orders is the challenge for the nation's defense contractors, analysts said. Three months ago that may have seemed unlikely with the Cold War turned tepid, but the Persian Gulf crisis has changed things again. The nation's two biggest contractors, McDonnell Douglas Corp. and General Dynamics, both stand to benefit from the reported sales, as will smaller contractors elsewhere. McDonnell Douglas, based in St. Louis, makes the F-15E jet fighter, which both the Saudis and Israelis want. The plane has never been sold to another country, though its predecessor, the F-15C, is flown in Japan, Israel and Saudi Arabia. Company aides declined to comment on the possibility of increased sales to other countries. The F-15E program is scheduled to build its final plane in mid-1992, although industry analysts expect the U.S orders to keep production going until mid-1993. Foreign sales could keep the program alive into 1996. ``Now's the time to make hay while the sun's shining. Let's get those orders nailed down and maybe we can stop any more layoffs down the road,'' said Cassell Williams, president of the company's largest union, the International Association of Machinists & Aerospace Workers. His union, which consists of almost 11,000 production and maintenance workers, has largely escaped the sweeping layoffs at McDonnell Douglas, which announced a plan in July to cut up to 17,000 jobs nationwide and save $700 million this year. About 100 of the union's members have been laid off, Williams said. The big cuts at the aerospace giant came at the white-collar level with middle managers and engineers baring the brunt. New overseas orders aren't likely to help them. ``The layoffs are being driven by our need to improve profitability. . .not by declines in the defense budget,'' said Barbara Anderson, a company spokeswoman. ``That means the upturn in military sales would have very little impact on the layoffs.'' At General Dynamics, based in the St. Louis suburb of Clayton, speculation about foreign orders for M1A2 tanks, F-16 jets and Stinger missiles also won't reverse plans to lay off 1,500 to 2,000 workers at two missile plants in Southern California by the end of 1991, spokesman Christopher Schildz said. ``We have not received any immediate, significant sales as a result of the Persian Gulf crisis and we have no way of predicting how the crisis will affect future sales,'' Schildz said. It's the same story at Lockheed Corp., based in Calabasas, Calif., which manufactured nearly all the transport planes used to move eguipment and troops to the Middle East and makes the radar-fooling Stealth aircraft that have been sent to the region. The company already has cut 5,500 jobs this year and is planning another 1,700 cuts to bring companywide employment to about 75,000 at the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Pattern Settlement Will Be Tough at Chrysler, Bidwell Says
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp.'s proposed pact with the United Auto Workers union would be too expensive for Chrysler Corp. to match, executives say. ``GM may have deep pockets and we don't,'' Chrysler Motors Chairman Bennett Bidwell said Wednesday. Chrysler especially objects to health-care provisions in the pact, which the union hopes to use as a pattern for contracts with Ford Motors Co. and Chrysler. The GM-UAW agreement carries over health-care provisions from the latest contract. Health-care costs are a big issue at Chrysler, which has more retirees and an older work force than GM or Ford Motors Co. Chrysler has about 60,000 active UAW-represented employees and almost the same number of retirees, who typically file more health claims than younger, active workers. Executives at Chrysler, which spent $684 million on health care last year, have said since bargaining began July 20 they would find it difficult to follow a pattern set with the larger, more profitable GM or Ford. But the pattern tradition is essential for the UAW. Chrysler workers are wearing buttons saying: ``Pattern or Picket.'' ``I'm hopeful that reasoned minds can come up with some ways to ease that burden a little bit without shattering the concept of pattern,'' Bidwell said. The UAW and GM reached a tentative labor agreement early Monday, two days after expiration of the existing contracts between the UAW and the Big Three. Talks with Ford and Chrysler were put on hold pending the outcome of GM talks and won't resume until the GM contract is voted on by rank-and-file union members later this month. The automakers said when they opened national contract negotiations with the UAW last July that health-care costs would be a major issue. At the opening of UAW-Chrysler negotiations, company Vice President Anthony St. John proposed a multi-employer health-care trust to hook Chrysler up with other companies. The result would be a large health-care group able to get lower health care rates by volume. The UAW rejected that idea. It appears Ford can live with the GM-UAW contract, although Chrysler may have to spend cash it's holding as a hedge against its weakened credit rating. Other portions of the GM-UAW agreement are disconcerting to Chrysler. GM has set aside $4 billion in income-protection programs that will pay full wages to workers laid off for more than 36 weeks over the next three years. ``On the surface, it looks expensive,'' Chrysler Motors President Robert Lutz said Wednesday. ``Job security is simply something that cannot be legislated.'' The UAW hasn't said whether it will bargain next at Chrysler or Ford. Ford's 12,800 workers in Canada struck over money issues for the fifth day Wednesday. Chrysler is expected to lose money in the third quarter, in part because of production time lost to retool its plants for new minivan models, the company's biggest sellers. Earnings in the first half of the year were 67 percent below last year and car and truck sales for the first eight months of the year were about 15 percent below last year. Two Japanese automakers, Honda Motor Co. Ltd. and Toyota Motor Corp., sell more cars in the United States than Chrysler. While it introduced several new and sporty cars Wednesday, the company still is short of new products for the early 1990s. Car buffs and analysts alike say much of Chrysler's product line is stale.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., British, Japanese Stock Watchdogs Meet
DOC.TEXT: Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden has enrolled British and Japanese regulators in his campaign to raise the amount of capital investors must put up to buy stock index futures on credit. Officials from Japan and Britain joined Breeden Wednesday in issuing a joint communique that called stated the need to maintain balance between stock markets and the markets for derivative products such as stock index futures contracts through higher margins. The joint statement was issued following 1{-days of meetings at a conference center in the rolling hill country of northern Virginia. In attendance were John Redwood, undersecretary for corporate affairs of Britain's Department of Trade and Industry; David Walker, chairman of the Securities and Investment Board for the United Kingdom; and Nobuhiko Matsuno, director-general of Japan's Securities Bureau of the Ministry of Finance. ``Given the internationalization of the world's securities markets, we felt it was important for the regulatory authorities of the three largest markets to have an opportunity to meet and review common concerns and common objectives,'' Breeden told reporters after the session ended. In their first three-way meeting, the regulators pledged to: encourage trading among their countries and expand their cooperative supervision of it; to strengthen formal agreements on the exchange of investigative information. But the section on margin levels was a small political coup for Breeden, who has been urging higher margins for stock index futures in this country. Stock index futures are a hybrid financial product that allow an investor to bet on the rise or fall of a number of stocks without having to buy the underlying securites that make up the index. And a margin is the down payment paid by an investor buying securities or futures contracts on credit. In the U.S. securities markets, margins are set by the Federal Reserve Board and are as high as 50 percent of the securities' price. In the futures markets, margins are set by the exchanges themselves and are generally far lower. Breeden and other critics of low futures margins claim they encourage risky trading practices that lead to sharp price swings in the markets. In their communique, the three regulators said that margin levels for stock index futures and other derivatives should be ``adequately high in the event of a sharp market decline.'' At a press briefing at the Georgian revival mansion where the conference was held, Walker, one of the British officials said they were glad to participate in a discussion of ``the general philosophy'' of margin control. While London's stock index futures and options markets were ``growing extremely rapidly'' the rate of growth was much less than in the United States or Japan. Matsuno said Japan had recently raised margin levels from 9 percent to 15 percent ``so as to recover the imbalance between the cash markets and the derivative markets'' although ``we have seen no notable effects of this.'' The United States has had memorandums of understanding with securities regulators in both Britain and Japan since 1986. But those pacts are limited in scope compared to subsequent agreements reached with other countries, such as Brazil and Switzerland, to exchange information and assist each other's investigations of fraud and other violations. Breeden said the focus of Wednesday's meeting was not reaching specific agreement on policy matters but ``on clearing away obstacles.'' In addition to margin levels, the regulators agreed to encourage cross-border business between markets in their countries by ``pursuing mutual recognition of regulatory systems,'' including disclosure requirements and systems for clearing and settling transactions. They also agreed to exchange information on a regular basis ``to the extent possible within legislative constraints'' to monitor multinational firms operating in all three countries. They renewed their intention to assist each others' investigations into securities law violations. The three said they have agreed to meet again in Britain in the late spring or early summer.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Faces Tough Times, Even with Lower Costs
DOC.TEXT: Despite cutbacks intended to save tens of millions of dollars, Pan Am Corp. faces turbulent times in a market that is proving tough even for healthier airlines. Pan Am said Wednesday it will eliminate 2,500 jobs from Pan American World Airways in a bid to become leaner and stronger. The troubled carrier will also reduce its capacity by 7.5 percent next year through a series of moves that will include the loss of some routes and the replacement of five large airplanes on trans-Atlantic flights with smaller planes that use less fuel. Pan Am Chairman Thomas G. Plaskett said the cutbacks will occur as Pan Am seeks to concentrate more business in Miami and Latin America, where its profits are the greatest. But Pan Am's success in becoming stronger is far from certain, analysts said. ``This is going to be a difficult thing for them to do, but it's not impossible,'' said George James, president of Airline Economics Inc., an aviation consulting firm in Washington. ``We face tough times,'' Pan Am spokesman Jeffrey F. Kriendler acknowledged. Plaskett said Pan Am's changes are being made in response to rising jet fuel costs and sluggish demand for air travel that have delt a particularly hard blow to ailing carriers. Pan Am reported losses of about $2 billion during the 1980s, and recent efforts to find a merger partner met no immediate success. Pan Am plans by mid October to eliminate the 2,500 jobs, from the ranks of management and labor that now total about 29,000. About 500 management jobs will be scrapped, Kriendler said. About half the cutback will likely be accomplished through layoffs, while Pan Am hopes to achieve the rest through attrition and voluntary leaves of absence. Pan Am was still trying to figure out where to make all the cuts, which will force remaining employees to work harder, Kriendler said. ``We know there will be no pilots affected,'' Kriendler said. ``About 550 are flight attendants, but all have agreed to take voluntary leaves of absence for three to nine months.'' Kriendler declined to offer more specifics about where the cuts might be made. He said Pan Am hopes to save tens of millions of dollars, but he would not be more precise. The Teamsters union, which represents about 6,500 of the Pan Am workers, issued a statement through its Airline Division on Wednesday saying Pan Am has indicated about 650 Teamsters would be laid off. Teamsters have periodically conducted scattered strikes against Pan Am in recent months, and the union said Wednesday it was hoping to stop truck deliveries at the key Kennedy Airport operation in New York and other Pan Am locations. Teamsters local leaders were meeting in Washington to discuss a more comprehensive strategy against Pan Am. The airline said its other moves were intended to reduce capacity by 7.5 percent in 1991. Pan Am will eliminate unprofitable feeder service into New York's Kennedy from Philadelphia; Pittsburgh; Austin and San Antonio, Texas; and Cincinnati. Pan Am's commuter subsidiary, Pan Am Express, would keep flying from Pittsburgh and Philadelphia into Kennedy, Plaskett told airline analysts during an afternoon meeting. As part of the cutbacks, Pan Am will stop leasing five of the 412-seat Boeing 747s now in its fleet of 35 and replace them with A310300s that carry less than half as many passengers, but also use less fuel. Plaskett said the larger planes are ideal for peak summer travel, but the smaller planes are more profitable on an annual basis. They will be assigned to flights from Kennedy to Milan, Italy, and Madrid, as well as on flights from Washington-Dulles to Frankfurt and London. Pan Am said it plans to get two new models of the smaller planes for next summer's peak season, flying them from New York to Zagreb, Yugoslavia, and from Newark, N.J., to London. Although the carrier's capacity will be down by 7.5 percent, departures will be down just 3.5 percent, and the number of miles flown will be down 2.3 percent when Pan Am's cutbacks are all put in place by April, Kriendler said.

DOC.HEAD: Commercial News Show Signs 4,200 Schools in 45 States
DOC.TEXT: The Channel One news show is back in operation, delivering 12 minutes a day of topical teen-oriented stories along with pitches for candy, sneakers and chips to classrooms in 45 states. Creators of Channel One say they are more than halfway toward their goal of signing 8,000 schools. But they have failed to shake the critics who contend it is wrong to deliver a captive audience of students to advertisers. Meanwhile, an advertising-free daily news program for use in the schools from the producers of Cable News Network is claiming a growing following. More than 12,000 schools have indicated interest in using the program CNN Newsroom in the classroom and executives at Turner Broadcasting System Inc. say their surveys indicate about half of those schools are using it regularly. Other cable TV networks, such as C-SPAN, The Discovery Channel and The Learning Channel, are either producing shows or stepping up efforts to promote existing ad-free services for use in the classroom. But it was Channel One, the commercial program from Whittle Communications of Knoxville, Tenn., that ignited a passionate debate about television's proper role in classroom education. Whittle tested its program in six schools in the spring of 1989, and made it available to schools nationwide starting this past March. Schools that agreed to show the program to all of their students every day got a loan of videocassette recorders, TV monitors for every classroom and wiring to tie the system together. They get to keep the equipment as long as they keep showing the program. That's been a tempting proposition for many schools that Whittle says would otherwise be poorly equipped to make use of TV programs that could help students learn. It is paying for the equipment and the costs of producing the daily news show by selling up to two minutes of commercial time in each 12-minute show. After taking the summer off, Channel One resumed programming at the end of August with an advertiser lineup that includes M&M-Mars Inc., Nike Inc., Frito-Lay Inc., Magnavox electronics and Columbia Pictures. Some advertisers have simply run ads touting products. But Nike has used some time for anti-drug messages and Burger King Corp. is using all its time for ads to discourage school dropouts. The shows itself use flashy graphics, maps and often tell stories from a teen perspective - Arab teens in the Mideast were interviewed in the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait about how their lives had been changed. Farrell Reynolds, a onetime Turner Broadcasting executive who now oversees Whittle's educational operations, said about 4,200 schools have signed three-year contracts to take Channel One and that 3,500 are actually receiving it. He said those schools have more than 3.1 million students and are in every state except Maine, Rhode Island, Nevada, Alaska and Hawaii. Public schools in New York, Rhode Island and California have been told they can either not accept ad-supported programs such as Channel One or risk losing state funds by carrying it. But Reynolds said parochial schools in the New York and Los Angeles areas have signed up. He said it is becoming easier to sell the program to schools and advertisers now that they can see what the shows are like. ``We are not getting complaints aboyut the advertising,'' he said. Paul Jones, superintendent at Southgate Community Schools in suburban Detroit, said students are used to seeing ads and pay little attention to those shown in school. He said teachers have used the ads to teach lessons about marketing and sales techniques. But the ads bother Pat Wright, principal at Carrollton High School 50 miles west of Atlanta and an avid subscriber to the ad-free CNN Newsroom show. ``I don't think you can talk to a class about Iraq and Kuwait for several minutes, take a 60-second (commercial) break ... and come back to it while keeping any consistency,'' he said. He said the ads also ``take unfair advantage of a captive audience'' of students who are required to be in school. John Kuglin, who uses CNN Newsroom every day with his fourth-grade class at Cold Springs School in Missoula, Mont., said he sees no need for a commercial news show because of the availability of an ad-free alternative. CNN Newsroom follows a format of news stories taken from regular CNN reports, a feature on a topic in science, technology, international events or business and a third segment devoted to a teen-oriented feature such as career opportunities. Like Channel One, it make liberal use of locator maps. CNN Newsroom was launched in August 1989, making its debut after Whittle completed the test of Channel One, but before Channel One went naitonal. The 15-minute show runs five days a week on CNN. Louis Pugliese, project director of Turner Educational Services, said there are no precise figures on how widely the program is used but estimated that about 6,000 schools use it regularly. While Turner offers no equipment to go with the show, he said several cable TV system operators have taken steps to see that schools can receive it and some have even donated TVs for use in the classroom.

DOC.HEAD: Ladies of the Night are Working for Uncle Sam Now
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto RO1
DOC.TEXT: Ladies of the night who have kept the red lights burning at America's best-known brothel have a new employer - Uncle Sam, by way of federal Bankruptcy Court. The Mustang Ranch, Nevada's oldest legal bordello, shut down Tuesday after filing for bankruptcy liquidation. On Wednesday, a court trustee took charge of the money-losing business until it can be sold or creditors are paid off. Prostitutes who had earlier fled out of fear that tax collectors were about to raid the place filtered back Wednesday, some to pick up belongings and others to resume work at the 105-room brothel. ``I want to come back, but I'm not going to work for no government,'' said a woman who identified herself only as Beth. ``A lot of girls don't like the idea of working for Uncle Sam,'' said 22-year-old Bree. ``They don't like the idea of having to pay taxes. But I know I'm going to give it a try. If I don't like it, I'll go to the Chicken Ranch outside Las Vegas.'' A lawyer for owner Joe Conforte said Internal Revenue Service harassment killed a $5 million deal to sell the bordello and forced it into liquidation. Officials said Conforte owes $13 million in federal taxes. Conforte put his debt at no more than $7 million. The Mustang was an illegal operation when Conforte and his wife, Sally, opened it on a 440-acre ranch 10 miles east of Reno in the 1950s. It became the state's first legal brothel in 1971. The bordello had been under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since 1982, meaning it operated under court supervision while it tried to pay off creditors. Two attempts to sell the business through stock offerings failed. Jeri Coppa, who previously managed smaller brothels in Nevada in her role as bankruptcy trustee, said she hopes to have the Mustang reopened for business by the weekend. She said officials from Bankruptcy Court will be on location at all times to make sure things run smoothly and that the government gets its due. ``My whole thing is if you're running a business, you're running a business,'' said Coppa. Plans to reopen immediately were blocked by state health rules, which require any prostitute who leaves the premises to be retested for sexually transmitted diseases. That can take three days. The prostitutes must undergo monthly checkups. Clients must wear condoms. Some 45 prostitutes, bartenders and floor supervisors signed up to resume work. Coppa said the IRS assured her it would not harass the women for back taxes. When the Mustang first opened, prostitution was tolerated but illegal in Nevada. It was burned down by local authorities in 1960 as a public nuisance. Conforte won Storey County approval for the brothel 11 years later, pioneering the movement to allow prostitution in 11 of Nevada's 18 counties. Prostitutes rented rooms at the ranch, which also got half their earnings. They accepted credit cards, in advance. Conforte fled to Brazil in 1981 after being convicted of tax evasion but returned in 1983 in a deal with prosecutors to testify against U.S. District Judge Harry Claiborne. Conforte claimed Claiborne took $85,000 in bribes. After a hung jury resulted in a mistrial, prosecutors dropped charges related to Conforte. Ultimately Claiborne was convicted of hiding more than $100,000 in income from the IRS. He was later impeached.

DOC.BYLINE: Olympia & York May Sell Minority Interest In Most U.S. Properties
DOC.TEXT: Olympia & York has hired an investment bank to sell a minority equity interest in most of its U.S. holdings, according to published reports. The private Toronto-based real estate company, which counts the World Financial Center in New York among its holdings, has hired Lazard Freres & Co. to handle the sale, the reports said. The amount of equity for sale was cited as almost 20 percent in one report and 25 percent in another. The company is also trying to refinance its Canary Wharf complex, Europe's largest real estate development of offices, stores and a hotel on the Thames River in London. The project is reportedly about 50 percent complete. The New York Times quoted unidentified Wall Street executives familiar with Olympia & York's recent business dealings as saying a chief reason for selling an interest in some of its U.S. holdings was to raise more cash for other projects, including the London project. The Times said the amount for sale is a 25 percent equity interest in most of Olympia and York's commercial properties in the United States. John Zucotti, president and chief executive of Olympia & York Companies USA, declined to tell the newspaper what percentage of which properties was being sold to partners. But one executive outside the company said Lazard had used the 25 percent figure in its talks with prospective institutional buyers. The Wall Street Journal, meanwhile, said the Reichmann family, which owns Olympia and York Developments Ltd., was seeking to sell almost a 20 percent interest in its massive U.S. real estate portfolio. The newspaper said real estate professionals said the interest could sell for between $200 million and $800 million. It said Zucotti denied speculation that the company has a cash-flow problem as many real estate concerns do. Zucotti told the newspaper the move was in the works for months and is intended to put intop the hands of a single institutional investor minority holdings in properties conrtrolled by a variety of Reichmann family members. The Journal said the properties involved include commercial projects in New York City, Boston, San Francisco and other major U.S. cities.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Gets $500 Million Loan From Airbus, GE
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines, heading into a tough earnings period sparked by the fuel crisis, has received a $500 million loan from General Electric Co. and European aircraft maker Airbus Industrie, a published report said today. The loan agreement may have given Airbus and GE an edge against competitors in securing a deal to sell Northwest 75 new planes, according to today's editions of the Wall Street Journal. Northwest's parent, St. Paul-based NWA Inc., recently agreed to order the Airbus A-320 aircraft and take options on 30 more in a deal valued at $4.6 billion. A GE joint venture is supplying is supplying engines for the aircraft. According to the Journal, Seattle's Boeing Co. also was competing to supply the planes to Northwest. Spokesmen for Northwest and GE were not immediately available for comment. But Alan Boyd, chairman of Airbus Industrie of North America, confirmed to the Journal that Airbus arranged the loan with Northwest during negotiations over the aircraft order. Boyd declined to say how much of the $500 million came from Airbus. He said the new planes will serve as collateral for the loans. Officials familiar with the transaction say the carrier plans to use the loan to repay debt resulting from its acquisition last year by an investor group that included Alfred A. Checci, the Journal reported. The group borrowed about $3 billion to buy the airline; about $1.7 billion of debt remains. The Journal said the deal reduces the chance that the carrier will face a cash crunch during a period of sharply higher fuel prices and soft domestic passenger traffic. Northwest says its fuel bill this year could increase by $180 million. To cope with higher fuel prices, Northwest raised fares 5.3 percent last month, and has slated an additional 4.2 percent increase for Oct. 1. But Northwest faces other financial hurdles. The carrier faces a Sept. 29 deadline for from the Department of Transportation to find a replacement for $225 million of a $400 million equity investment from KLM Royal Dutch Airlines. The Journal said, however, that the government is likely to grant the carrier an extension.

DOC.HEAD: EC Oil Stocks Have Risen Since August
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's oil stocks have risen since early August, a senior official of the organization said Thursday. Antonio Cardoso e Cunha, the EC's energy commissioner, said inventories were up despite the break in oil supplies from Iraq and Kuwait. He said the EC believed ``stocks must be kept for a graver situation,'' warning that an ``unjustified signal of instability,'' would be sent if the International Energy Agency recommended its members began drawing on their inventories. Cardoso e Cunha said he could not put a figure on the EC's oil reserves but noted the 105 days of oil consumption stocks recorded in early August was ``very comfortable.'' Questioned on whether the EC could replace its former Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude imports with oil from the Soviet Union, the commissioner said that ``under present technical circumstances we cannot replace our dependency on Middle East sources.'' He said the lost Kuwaiti and Iraqi production was being replaced by other Middle Eastern sources. But he said energy opportunities in the Soviet Union were a ``key point'' in current trade and economic cooperation talks with Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Sony Introduces New DAT Lineup
DOC.TEXT: Sony Corp. has announced a new lineup of digital audio tape recorders that includes a Walkman-size model, saying it believes the technology will duplicate the success of compact discs. The new equipment, known as DAT, and CDs use computer-like digital signals to reproduce sound, but DAT machines also allow consumers to make recordings that can rival studio equipment in sound quality. The new Sony DAT lineup features two top-of-the-line machines, a car player, and a Walkman weighing 1.4 pounds including rechargeable battery. It will go on sale in North America and Europe in December and January. ``Sony believes 1991 will be a year of takeoff for DAT,'' Kozo Ohsone, senior general manager of Sony's Audio Group, said Wednesday. ``We see a growing market for DAT, linked to the growing importance of digital equipment.'' Ohsone said he believes sales of DAT equipment will follow the pattern of CDs and become widely popular in two or three years. Sony said the DAT Walkman, to be marketed in Japan for $710, is the first that includes all circuitry needed for recording from both digital sources such as CDs, and analog sources such as microphones. ``It's Walkman for hi-fi maniacs,'' a Sony official said. Portable DAT machines also have been announced by Aiwa, Sharp, Hitachi and JVC. The car player, with a built-in FM-AM tuner, will go on sale in Japan in December for $870, Sony said. It uses a new technology in which each track on the tape is read twice by a spinning head and the better version selected to minimize the effect of vibration, Sony said. All of the new machines also can play at half speed, allowing up to four hours of playback time but at reduced sound quality. Although DAT recorders were first introduced in Japan three years ago, sales have been slow because of their high cost, the lack of prerecorded tapes, and opposition from record companies worried that DAT's ability to make near-perfect copies would encourage record piracy. But last year, international record and electronic industry groups agreed on a new DAT technical standard which prohibits the machines from being used in making second-generation recordings from CDs. Equipment using the standard was first introduced this summer around the world, including in the United States. ``The response was greater than we expected, and as a result we are introducing a full range of DAT equipment,'' Ohsone said. He said Sony has sold about 30,000 of its current DAT model in the two months since then, with about 70 percent of the sales in Japan. DAT is likely to face continued sales resistance because of the prices, which are only moderately lower than models already on the market. But its chief threat in the future may be other emerging technologies, such as recordable CDs and a new digital tape system being developed by Philips. ``The technology is already developed. It's just a matter of what will sell,'' Ohsone said.

DOC.HEAD: American General May Sell Only Core Unit
DOC.TEXT: American General Corp., which has tried unsuccessfully to find a buyer for the whole company, said it may settle for divesting only its large insurance unit. The board of directors of the Houston-based financial services concern announced Wednesday that a new restructuring plan calls for the sale of its home service life insurance business, which represents more than half of American General's operating earnings. The rest of American General's operations in consumer finance, real estate and mutual funds would be retained as a public company under the new plan. ``In May of this year, we committed ourselves to maximizing current shareholder values through the sale of the company as a whole,'' the directors said in a news release. ``This marketing effort has been unsuccessful to date, but the restructuring plan provides an alternative for maximizing shareholder value in the near term, through the tax-advantaged sale of our most significant business segment,'' the release said. The news sent American General stock reeling Wednesday. It tumbled $6.37{ a share to $33.62{ in composite New York Stock Exchange trading. American General stock had traded as high as $50.62{ a share earlier this year when it was facing a $50-a-share takeover bid from Torchmark Corp. American General turned down Torchmark's offer. The home services operation would include companies that concentrate on the sale and service of traditional insurance products directly through employee agents. These businesses have assets of $8.9 billion, equity of $3 billion and generated earnings of $305 million in 1989. The main businesses of a restructured American General would include a tax-qualified annuities unit, real estate operations and a consumer finance subsidiary. Together, they have assets of $24.9 billion and equity of $3.5 billion. In 1989, those American General businesses earned $235 million. Harold S. Hook, chairman and chief executive officer of American General, said the board opted to consider a restructuring given the ``current international and economic uncertainty,'' which has discouraged potential interest in the company in its entirety. The restructuring plan was not a result of ``active negotiations'' with any one buyer, the board said. The plan would have to be approved by the Internal Revenue Service and by certain federal and state regulators. American General has subsidiaries operating in all 50 states and Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Philips Withdraws From Joint Venture With AT&T
DOC.TEXT: NV Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, on Thursday confirmed a week-old rumor that it would sell its 15 percent stake in a telephone equipment company set up jointly with American Telephone & Telegraph Co. Philips said it was selling its share in AT&T Network System International to its U.S. partner, but spokesman Cor Vreven denied the transaction was part of a cost-cutting operation begun this summer by the company's recently appointed chairman, Jan Timmer. AT&T's share in the joint venture, based in the Dutch city of Hilversum, is being boosted from 59 to 74 percent as a result of Philips' withdrawal. The venture, founded in 1984, makes sophisticated electronic switching devices for public telephone systems. Philips and AT&T inititally held equal shares, but Philips gradually reduced its holding. Last week, AT&T sold 6 percent of its stake in the venture to Telefonica de Espana SA of Spain. The other partner in the venture is the Italian Stet Group, at 20 percent. Vreven said the sale won't affect the other activities of Philips' telecommunication division, which employs about 15,000 people and develops and manufacturers equipment for data communication, radio, rural telephone, public cable transmission and network management systems. Timmer warned July 2 that as many as 10,000 Philips' jobs might be lost worldwide under the restructuring and projected a loss of up to $1 billion despite the job reductions.
