DOC.HEAD: Xerox Introduces Workstation, Software To Bring Far-Flung Offices Together
DOC.TEXT: Co-workers who are based in far-flung offices worldwide will be able to collaborate on projects using a new computer and software from Xerox Corp. The key technology, announced Wednesday, isn't the computer Xerox introduced - a $10,000 workstation made by Sun Microsystems Inc. - but the machine's basic software, called GlobalView. ``GlobalView will help project teams scattered throughout different locations in mid- to large-size companies accomplish more and in far less time than previously possible,'' said Joseph McGrath, vice president of marketing for Xerox Integrated Systems Operations. GlobalView combines many of the basic features of an office computer, such as software to do word processing and printing, along with special functions to automate the tasks of groups of workers who collaborate on projects. Based on shared ``documents'' that combine text, graphics, spreadsheet tables and other data, GlobalView lets a worker manipulate the information even when it is on a distant computer. The changes are instantly available to the worker's colleagues through the company's computer network. So far, few such ``groupware'' products have been brought to market, and buyers have been reluctant to embrace the ill-defined concept. Xerox hopes its software, along with an integrated printer and electronic scanner it intends to unveil in the next month, will persuade buyers they can benefit from groupware, thus raising Xerox's low visibility in the computer industry. ``What they're trying to do here is (make) a broad offering of interest to companies with offices around the world,'' said Vera Allen-Smith, an industry analyst with Dataquest Inc., a high-technology h firm in San Jose. GlobalView is based on the company's Viewpoint software, which until now worked only on Xerox's proprietary computers. It has been modified to run under Sun's version of AT&T's Unix operating system on the new Xerox 6520 workstation, which is being manufactured for Xerox by Sun. Xerox also announced a $3,995 kit that lets GlobalView run under IBM's OS-2 operating system, which is designed for personal computers. The kit includes the software, a 19-inch black-and-white monitor and an add-in board for the IBM Personal Computer AT and compatible machines. Analysts said one problem Xerox may face with the software is that it is designed with an out-of-date ``user interface,'' the on-screen graphics and symbols through which the user controls the computer. The user interface is similar to the one Xerox invented in the 1970s. Other companies, notably Apple Computer Inc., have made so many improvements to the Xerox interface, which includes a mouse and a screen partioned into windows, that the Xerox system is now far out of the mainstream, analysts said.

DOC.HEAD: Say Trump Misses Loan Payment, Wants Delay on Shuttle Loan Payments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with comments from Trump executive. No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Developer Donald J. Trump has failed to make a $1.1 million loan payment for the Trump Shuttle and is seeking to reschedule $245 million in loans on the airline, a top aide said today. The missed payment and delay request comes less than a month after the beleaguered real estate-gambling entrepreneur concluded a $65 million bank bailout critical to keeping other elements of his empire afloat. The Wall Street Journal said Trump and two aides met Wednesday with officials from Citibank, asking the bank to restructure debt payments on the shuttle, which provides service on the Boston-New York-Washington corridor. Stephen Bollenbach, chief financial officer of the Trump Organization, confirmed today that the meeting had occurred and said bank officials ``have been very encouraging so far in helping us through these problems.'' He said Trump had failed to make a $1.1 million payment that came due in the past few days. He declined to say whether that payment would be made. ``It's too early to get into a discussion of terms of the restructuring,'' he said in a telephone interview. The Journal story said Trump was expected to make the payment, but is not expected to be able to keep up with payments estimated at about $30 million due in the next 12 months. He said Citibank had prepared a memo to other banks that bought pieces of the loan dealing with the requested rescheduling and that he expected another meeting between Trump officials and the banks would be set up for next week. Officials at Citibank declined comment on the matter. Bollenbach said the primary reason for requested rescheduling was the depressed state of the economy in the Northeast which has led to a sharp decline in traffic and revenue on the shuttle route. ``The whole market is down,'' he said, referring to both the Trump Shuttle and its main competitor, the Pan Am Shuttle. In addition, he said the cost of fuel has ``more than doubled'' since early summer. Fuel prices have soared in the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, which raised the risk of a supply disruption from the region. Bollenbach said shuttle managers are operating the airline efficiently, and that the banks were being told that the shuttle had become unprofitable for reasons ``totally outside of management's control.'' The $245 million in loans at issue in the latest talks were not included in the discussions that led last month to the $65 million bank bailout on about $1 billion of Trump's $2 billion bank debt, Bollenbach said. The loans under discussion were part of the money Trump borrowed to buy the shuttle from Eastern Airlines for $365 million in 1989.
